Dracula’s Lineage Speech
If anyone for any reason would appreciate a blow by blow breakdown of everything that is going on in the Count’s lineage speech, matching all of Dracula’s dialogue to Stoker’s research sources and describing the historical events being alluded to, I made one of those many many years ago and I’ve copy/pasted it under the cut:
Pre-History:
 Various sub-groups of the Finno-Ugric language 
group split from one another. These proto-Magyars, Dracula claims, are 
the blood that begot the legends of 
berserkir
 and werewolves. (In
 reality, the berserker myth is characteristic of North Germanic peoples
 which Stoker seems to have confused with Northern Finno-Ugric groups 
like the Finns.)
Dracula:
 "Here, in the whirlpool of European races, the
 Ugric tribe bore down from Iceland the fighting spirit which Thor and 
Wodin gave them, which their Berserkers displayed to such fell intent, 
which their Berserkers displayed to such fell intent on the seaboards of
 Europe, aye, and of Asia and Africa too, till the peoples thought that 
the werewolves themselves had come."
Stoker's Source
(s)
:

 "...Max Müller, by the unerring guide of language, has traced the 
original seat of this interesting people [the Magyars] to the Ural 
mountains which stretch upwards to the Arctic ocean; and pointing out 
the close affinity the Magyar tongue bears to the idiom of the Finnish 
race spoken east of the Volga, declares that the Magyars form the fourth
 branch of the Finnish stock, viz. the Ugric; and in his 'Science of 
Language' he gives striking examples of the similarity and connection 
which exist in the grammatical structure of the Magyar and the 
Ugro-Finnish dialects, particularly in the conjugation of verbs, which 
have aptly been called the "bones and sinews" of a language; and there 
is little doubt that the Magyars are none other than the same race that,
 under a different name, were called in the fourth century "Ugrogs." 
(Nina Mazuchelli's 
Maygarland
, Chapter IV, pg. 45)
335 B.C.E.:
 The Getæ tribe of the Carpathian basin is defeated
 by Alexander the Great, which E. C. Johnson claims marks the point at 
which they began to be called the Dacians.
Stoker's Source
(s)
:

 The first record which we have of these provinces refers to a people 
called the Getæ, whose name was changed to Dacians, after their defeat 
by Alexander the Great, in the fourth century B.C 
(E. C. Johnson's 
On the Track of the Crescent
, Chapter VIII, pg. 105)
101-105 C.E.:
 The Dacians are conquered by Emperor Trajan and 
fall under Roman rule. Eventually, Rome withdraws from Dacia in 274 C. 
E., leaving the area open to incursions by the Visigoths.
Stoker's Source(s):
 It is sufficiently ascertained that
 these two provinces, joined to those of Transylvania and Temesvar, 
composed the kingdom of Dacia, finally conquered by the Romans. 
(William Willinkson's 
An Account of the Principalities of Wallachia and Moldavia
, Chapter I, pg. 45)
376 C.E.:
 Dacia is invaded by the Huns.
Dracula:
 "Here, too, when they came, they found the 
Huns, whose warlike fury had swept the earth like a living flame, till 
the dying peoples held that in their veins ran the blood of those old 
witches, who, expelled from Scythia had mated with the devils in the 
desert."
Stoker's Source
(s)
:

 “Geographically situated to be the 'war ground' of Europe, these 
unfortunate Danubian provinces were open to inroads from all sides, and 
the barbarians made them happy hunting-grounds for human game; the 
wretched Roman colonists, who had elected to remain behind with their 
Dacian co-inhabitants, having a rough time of it. In 376 A.D. the Huns 
paid Dacia a 'morning call,' and subdued it, driving out the Goths. 
These fierce Scythians are not flatteringly described by Gibbon, to 
whose delightful pages I must refer my readers for details of their 
personal appearance, &c.” 
(E. C. Johnson's 
On the Track of the Crescent
, Chapter VIII, pg. 106)
453 - 454 C.E.:
 Attila, from whom the Székely ethnic group 
(and Dracula) claim descent, dies in his tent. Afterwards, the subjects
 of the Huns unite under the Gepid ruler Ardaric, and break Hunnish 
control over the region a year later following the Battle at the River 
Nedao.
Dracula:
 "Fools, fools! What devil or what witch was ever so great as Attila, whose blood is in these veins?"
Stoker's Source(s):
 "They won, under their famous King 
Attila, a constant succession of victories against the Romans, till 
Attila's death in A.D. 453, and were then driven out of Dacia by the 
Gepidæ, a tribe of Goths..” 
(E. C. Johnson's 
On the Track of the Crescent
, Chapter VIII, pg. 106)

 “The Székelys – who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns – 
were found settled on the eastern frontier when the country was 
conquered by the Magyars, and the two races at once fraternised.” 
(E. C. Johnson's 
On the Track of the Crescent
, Chapter I, pg. 20)
567 - 670 C.E.:
 King Albion of the Lombards and Bayan I of the
 Avars unite to overtake Gepida. They do so in 567, killing the last 
Gepid king, Cunimund. Over a century later the Avars will fall under the
 control of the First Bulgarian Empire.
Dracula:
 "Is it a wonder that we were a conquering 
race, that we were proud, that when the Magyar, the Lombard, the Avar, 
the Bulgar, or the Turk poured his thousands on our frontiers, we drove 
them back?"
Stoker's Source(s):
 "The country was afterwards 
successively held by the Lombards, Avars, and Bulgars. The last named 
were, according to Gibbon, a nomad people from Russia and Poland, who 
sacrificed human beings, and indulged in polygamy. They overran Dacia, 
Thrace, Epirus, and Thessaly, and advanced as far as the Peloponnesus, 
till defeated by Belisarius (538-540 A.d.) and driven back to Dacia, 
where they finally obtained ascendancy over the Avars, 678-680.” 
(E. C. Johnson's 
On the Track of the Crescent
, Chapter I, pg. 106)
892-895 C.E.:
 The Magyar prince, Árpád, conquers the region of
 the Carpathian basin and the Magyar people (descended from the Ugric 
group of early history) begin to settle there. This event will become 
known as the Honfoglalás. It is at this point that Dracula claims the 
Székelys (already in the Carpathians) are recognized as kindred to the 
Magyars.
Dracula:
 "Is it strange that when Árpád and his legions
 swept through the Hungarian fatherland he found us here when he reached
 the frontier, that the Honfoglalás was completed there? And when the 
Hungarian flood swept eastward, the Székelys were claimed as kindred by 
the victorious Magyars, and to us for centuries was trusted the guarding
 of the frontier of Turkeyland. Aye, and more than that, endless duty of
 the frontier guard, for as the Turks say, 'water sleeps, and the enemy 
is sleepless.' Who more gladly than we throughout the Four Nations 
received the 'bloody sword,'or at its warlike call flocked quicker to 
the standard of the King?"
Stoker's Source(s):
 "...he drew himself up proudly 
until he almost stood on tip-toe, and with a look expressive of triumph 
replied, "En Magyar vagyok" ("I am a Magyar"), and went on to inform us 
that he was the grandson of an unfortunate noble whose lands had been 
forfeited, but whose descent could be traced to the honfoglalas, as the 
conquest of the Hungarian fatherland by Arpád in the ninth century is 
called, – an event regarded by the Magyars in the same light as we 
ourselves view the Norman Conquest." 
(Nina Mazuchelli's 
Maygarland,
 Chapter V, pg. 203)
 
“The Székelys have played a very important part in the history
 of Hungary and Transylvania. They were recognised as kindred by the 
Magyars on their first entering Hungary, and the two races have remained
 allies ever since. The Székelys also received certain privileges in 
return for their having guarded the frontier towards Moldavia and 
'Turkey-land.'" 
(E. C. Johnson's
 On the Track of the Crescent
, Chapter XIX, pgs. 234)
 “Water sleeps and the enemy is sleepless” 
(William Willinkson's 
An Account of the Principalities of Wallachia and Moldavia
, Appendix 5, Section II, pg. ) 

 “Formerly, only nobles could hold land in Hungary. They paid no taxes, 
but were obliged to assemble their retainers, and flock to the king's 
standard, on receipt of the 'bloody sword,' as a signal of national 
emergency.” 
(E. C. Johnson's 
On the Track of the Crescen
t, Chapter XVIII, pg. 228) 
1444 C.E.: 
Władysław III, King of Hungary, is in the midst of 
the Varna Campaign, which aims to expel the Ottomans from Europe. Janos 
Hunyadi (Hungarian military leader and Voïvode of Transylvania) demands 
that Vlad II Dracul of Wallachia join the effort against the Turks as 
Władysław's vassal. Vlad II declines, and his son, Mircea II, joins the 
campaign instead. Later that year, Wladyslaw III dies at the battle of 
Varna.
Stoker's Source(s):
 "The Hungarians being defeated at 
the celebrated battle of Varna, Hunniades their general, and regent of 
the kingdom during Ladislas's minority, returned in haste to make new 
preparations for carrying on the war. But the Voïvode, fearful of the 
Sultan's vengeance, arrested and kept him prisoner during a year, 
pretending thereby to show to the Turks that he treated him as an enemy.
 The moment Hunniades reached Hungary, he assembled an army and placed 
himself at the head of it, returned to Wallachia, attacked and defeated 
the Voïvode, and caused him to be beheaded in his presence; after which 
he raised to the Voïvodate one of the primates of the country, of the 
name of Dan. ." (William Wilkinson's An Account of the Principalities of
 Wallachia and Moldavia, Chapter I, pg. 18-19)
 [No notes taken by Stoker on this section]
1444-1447 C.E.: 
Vlad II Dracul captures and temporarily 
imprisons Hunyadi as he returns from his defeat at Varna. Later, Hunyadi
 (now regent of Hungary) conspires with local boyars to assassinate Vlad
 II and Mircea (who is allegedly blinded with hot pokers and buried 
alive).
Stoker's Source(s):
 "The Hungarians being defeated at 
the celebrated battle of Varna, Hunniades their general, and regent of 
the kingdom during Ladislas's minority, returned in haste to make new 
preparations for carrying on the war. But the Voïvode, fearful of the 
Sultan's vengeance, arrested and kept him prisoner during a year, 
pretending thereby to show to the Turks that he treated him as an enemy.
 The moment Hunniades reached Hungary, he assembled an army and placed 
himself at the head of it, returned to Wallachia, attacked and defeated 
the Voïvode, and caused him to be beheaded in his presence; after which 
he raised to the Voïvodate one of the primates of the country, of the 
name of Dan. ." (William Wilkinson's An Account of the Principalities of
 Wallachia and Moldavia, Chapter I, pg. 18-19)
 [No notes taken by Stoker on this section]
1448-1460 C.E.:
 Hunyadi is defeated by the Ottomans under 
Murad II at the Battle of Kosovo. He continues his campaigns against the
 Ottomans until his death in 1456.
Dracula:
 "When was redeemed that great shame of my 
nation, the shame of Cassova, when the flags of the Wallach and the 
Magyar went down beneath the Crescent?"
Stoker's Source(s):
 “The Wallachians under this Voïvode
 joined again the Hungarians in 1448, and made war on Turkey; but being 
totally defeated at the battle of Cossova, in Bulgaria, and finding it 
no longer possible to make any stand against the Turks, they submitted 
again to the annual tribute, which they paid until the year 1460, when 
the Sultan Mahomet II., being occupied in completing the conquest of the
 islands in the Archipelago, afforded them a new opportunity of shaking 
off the yoke.” (William Wilkinson's An Account of the Principalities of 
Wallachia and Moldavia, Chapter I, pg. 18-19)
1460-1461 C.E.:
 Vlad III (son of Vlad II) wages a bloody 
campaign against the Ottomans in alliance with Hungarian monarch 
Matthias Corvinus (son of John Hunyadi).
Dracula:
 "Who was it but one of my own race who as 
Voïvode crossed the Danube and beat the Turk on his own ground? This was
 a Dracula indeed!"
Stoker's Source(s):
 "Their Voïvode, also named Dracula,
 did not remain satisfied with mere prudent measures of defence: with an
 army he crossed the Danube and attacked the few Turkish troops that 
were stationed in his neighbourhood; but this attempt, like those of his
 predecessors, was only attended with momentary success.” (William 
Wilkinson's An Account of the Principalities of Wallachia and Moldavia, 
Chapter I, pg. 18-19)
1462 C.E.:
 Radu the Handsome (Vlad III's brother who allied 
with the Ottomans and became a Muslim convert) lays siege to Poenari 
Castle and is appointed the "Bey of Wallachia" by Mehmed II. Vlad III, 
in the meantime, appeals to Corvinus and is arrested and imprisoned.
Dracula:
 "Woe was it that his own unworthy brother, 
when he had fallen, sold his people to the Turk and brought the shame of
 slavery on them!"
Stoker's Source(s):
 "Mahomet having turned his arms 
against him, drove him [Vlad III] back to Wallachia, whither he pursued 
and defeated him. The Voïvode escaped into Hungary, and the Sultan 
caused his brother Bladus [Radu] to be named in his place. He made a 
treaty with Bladus, by which he bound the Wallachians to perpetual 
tribute; and laid the foundations of that slavery, from which no efforts
 have yet had the power of extricating them with any lasting efficacy." 
(William Wilkinson
's An Account of the Principalities of Wallachia and Moldavia,
 Chapter I, pg. 18-19)
1526 C.E.:
 Suleiman the Magnificent defeats Hungarian forces 
at the Battle of Mohacs, which results in the partition of Hungary, with
 Transylvania becoming a technically independent principality paying 
tribute to the Ottoman Empire.
Dracula:
 Again, when, after the battle of Mohács, we 
threw off the Hungarian yoke, we of the Dracula blood were amongst their
 leaders, for our spirit would not brook that we were not free."
Stoker's Source(s): 
“After the battle of Mohacs, which 
extinguished Hungarian independence, Transylvania fell into the hands of
 'the unspeakable,' who made it an independent principality under the 
protection of the Porte; the country being governed by princes who were 
elected by the people, subject to the approval of the Sultan.” (E.C. 
Johnson's 
On the Track of the Crescent
, Chapter XVI, pg. 206) 
???? C.E.:
 An unknown "Dracula" of a later age (than Vlad II and III) crosses the Danube and fights against the Turks.
Dracula:
 "Was it not this Dracula, indeed, who inspired
 that other of his race who in a later age again and again brought his 
forces over the great river into Turkeyland, who, when he was beaten 
back, came again, and again, though he had to come alone from the bloody
 field where his troops were being slaughtered, since he knew that he 
alone could ultimately triumph!"
Stoker's Source(s):
 Unknown. The description of a 
"Dracula" who crossed the Danube could apply to a number of historical 
figures. Stoker took some notes on Voïvode Michael the Brave (who was a 
member of the Drăculești blood line and campaigned against the Turks) 
from Wilkinson (pg. 26), but his notes focus not on his military 
actions, but rather on the popular opposition to his appointment as Vo
ï
vode of Transylvania.
Stoker also took notes on Voïvode Constantin Brâncoveanu, 
regarding his refusal to take an active part in a campaign led by Ahmed 
III. (pg. 32)

Okay, so. I am so psyched that a whole new cohort of people is discovering the wonderful hot mess that is the original Dracula. It’s so much weirder than it gets credit for. Like, the movie adaptations don’t go nearly hard enough. There are so many gems coming up and I can’t wait for folks to be introduced.
Would anyone here who has already read Dracula be interested in doing a readalong sometime of Powers of Darkness: the lost version of Dracula? This has been on my list since it came out in English in 2016 and I finally got a physical copy of it on indie bookstore day.
It’s honestly wild that Powers of Darkness exists. It was 
supposed to
 be a Swedish translation published in serial. However, the anonymous translator just straight up added chapters, changed significant plot elements, moved things around, and did whatever they liked. After the serial was published in Swedish, it was released as a novel in Icelandic the following year.
The Icelandic novel was thought to be just an abridged translation for the longest time because back in the 1890s you could just get away with shit. If you acted confident no one would check you.
Anyway, you don’t have to answer now. I just think it would be fun to talk about Powers of Darkness with folks after they’ve read the original novel.

Dracula

I forgot how much I love the imagery in Dracula. It's excellent at matching Harker's mood in the moment. Here's a couple of my favourite bits from May 5:
There was everywhere a bewildering mass of fruit blossom—apple, plum, pear, cherry; and as we drove by I could see the green grass under the trees spangled with the fallen petals.
the road, losing itself as it swept round the grassy curve, or was shut out by the straggling ends of pine woods, which here and there ran down the hillsides like tongues of flame.
the snowy mountain-top still held the sunset, and seemed to glow out with a delicate cool pink
in the self-surrender of devotion to have neither eyes nor ears for the outer world.
the ordinary peasant's cart—with its long, snake-like vertebra, calculated to suit the inequalities of the road.
the mountains seemed to come nearer to us on each side and to frown down upon us
I expected to see the glare of lamps through the blackness; but all was dark. The only light was the flickering rays of our own lamps, in which the steam from our hard-driven horses rose in a white cloud.
the moon, sailing through the black clouds, appeared behind the jagged crest of a beetling, pine-clad rock, and by its light I saw around us a ring of wolves, with white teeth and lolling red tongues, with long, sinewy limbs and shaggy hair. They were a hundred times more terrible in the grim silence which held them than even when they howled. 
I am all in a sea of wonders.

Years ago, learning that somehow I hadn't read Dracula or seen any of its adaptations, my sister lent me her copy of the book. It was a beautiful black hardcover book with a dramatic illustration of a red eyed Dracula on top of the title. I said I would take care of it and then, tragically, only got a few chapters in before my cat locked eyes with it at night, threw it from my nightstand  and munched and ripped two chapters to shreds while I somehow slept through it all. I felt like the kid that truthfully has to say their dog ate their homework, but thankfully my sister was very understanding of our cat's midnight lunacy. It wasn't her favourite book or anything, but she was sad about it because it was a very cool copy. In the end, with time we both promptly forgot about it all. 
Fastforward some years later, I am at a bookshop and I see this beautiful clothbound Dracula copy, hardcover with a black castle and iridiscent blue details. The memory of my sister's shredded copy rushes back to me and I decide, yeah why not, I'll buy this one, read it once and for all, and then gift it back to her. 
That was last week, on May 1st, imagine my surprise when I opened tumblr three days later and found everyone going bananas about reading this same 1897 book via emails. Anyways, whether you found it from the hilarious real-time chronological chain of emails that is dracula daily or have been delayed from reading it by a paper-eating feline rage, fate has indeed brought us all together to read Bram Stoker's Dracula in 2022. I'm okay with that. Cheers and good reading.

body: i think one of the things that’s so fun about dracula daily is that it’s encouraging readers to have fun with the source material. i feel like there’s this pervasive idea that classics have to be taken very seriously and while they absolutely can be- sometimes it’s easier & more meaningful to read a classic like you’d read any other book. something i love about dd right now is that people are making memes about it and joking and i feel like the desire for levity is such a communal human urge. i just finished wuthering heights and it’s disappointing to go into the tag on here or any other website and see that it’s all #dark academia aesthetic posts. i feel like a lot of people are reading classics just to say they read the classics and i’m definitely guilty of that too sometimes. however, the more i read classics, the more i have fun with them! and i’m still able to engage with the complex themes of these novels while having fun. free urself from the idea of reading books the “right” way or the “smart” way. just read the books and have a good time! 🕺

“It looks like part of a keep, and is close to an old chapel or church. I could not enter it, as I had not the key of the door leading to it from the house, but I have taken with my kodak views of it from various points.”
-Dracula Daily, May 7th. 
The thing that messes with me about Dracula is how recent it is. It always throws me that the above quotation has Jonathan taking photos with a camera and showing them to Dracula. It just messes with me because I think of that as such an old book, set far in the past. It messes with me that cars were a thing in the world of Dracula. I think of it as such a chronologically ancient book that might be from the middle ages or something like that. The fact that I knew people in my childhood who were born only five years after the events of this book take place is so mystifying to me.￼￼
For a literary anthology, I wrote a story (which was rejected) about a vampire in the wild West and I needed the townsfolk to know what a vampire was. The fact that the very first major book in the West (outside of Eastern Europe) that talked about vampires was this one from 1897, after the wild West was over made it very difficult. I needed to choose one of the first vampire books by John Polidori from the beginning of the 1800s as a way to introduce the concept of the vampire to a bunch of random locals in a town in the west. If anybody is interested, feel free to comment or whatever if you want me to post the story. I think it’s pretty good.￼￼

"The estate is called Carfax, no doubt a corruption of the old 
Quatre Face
, as the house is four-sided, agreeing with the cardinal points of the compass. It contains in all some twenty acres, quite surrounded by the solid stone wall above mentioned. There are many trees on it, which make it in places gloomy, and there is a deep, dark-looking pond or small lake, evidently fed by some springs, as the water is clear and flows away in a fair-sized stream. The house is very large and of all periods back, I should say, to mediæval times, for one part is of stone immensely thick, with only a few windows high up and heavily barred with iron. It looks like part of a keep, and is close to an old chapel or church. I could not enter it, as I had not the key of the door leading to it from the house, but I have taken with my kodak views of it from various points. The house has been added to, but in a very straggling way, and I can only guess at the amount of ground it covers, which must be very great. There are but few houses close at hand, one being a very large house only recently added to and formed into a private lunatic asylum. It is not, however, visible from the grounds."
Say what you will about Dracula, but you can't say he doesn't have good taste in real estate.  I too would like a stone house oriented to the compass points, with a stream on the grounds, and an asylum nearby, but conveniently hidden from line-of-sight.

So Dracula is like every ESL person you meet when you’re an English person on holiday. Like,
“Do you speak English?” you say in their language, one of the only sentences you remember from your 2 week duolingo marathon.

I saw someone giving poor Harker a hard time for resolving to ask YOUR FRIEND DRACULA about the crazy local superstitions rather than the crazy superstitious locals themselves but like, two things:
First, Dracula speaks English.  Our boy Jon has been getting by as best he can on his high-school German, which is not the native language here to start with (it's famously diglossic, it's complicated).  He's going to be having time to talk to his host in his own language at his leisure later - that makes more sense than trying to stumble through in German while he's anxious about missing his coach
Second he.  He literally has been trying to talk to people this whole time.  They either suddenly forget how to speak German or fall to their knees crying and crossing themselves.  People are consistently super unwilling to talk to him about this stuff
Anyway he's doing his Best, he doesn't deserve this kind of calumny.  Especially when [spoiler redacted]

body:
Ok I’m rethinking my stance on the ‘I couldn’t be Jonathan’ problem. Yesterday I said I would for sure be Jonathan because I would 100% continue on to the haunted castle honestly because of, not despite, all the warnings. Rethinking today. I couldn’t be Jonathan because I am too Catholic to be Jonathan. 
Do you know how many rosaries I’ve accepted from strangers? 
(Ok it happened one time but it was delightful and I would do it again) 
I would still roll up to Dracula’s castle but I would be practically cocooned in anti-vampire charms, reeking of garlic. Every suggested weird ritual I would go all in on. I would for sure still go and unfortunately for me I would repel the vampires because I got overexcited by the village superstition and folk practice. Poor Protestant Jonathan Harker. Couldn’t be me.

tags: once hes in that carriage his whole freedom is reliant on his host
body:
Related to that last post, but a lot of people keep saying they would see all the red flags and immediately leave--and I want to call bullshit.
You just finished your big bar exam, and you've been PROMOTED. Your boss is sending you cross continent to deal with a big time buyer, but some of the locals are acting weird and you say you're just gonna LEAVE? How would you explain that, "the vibes are bad"? You aint ever gonna get hired in your field again, and all you can say as an excuse is that people were saying weird stuff to you--when you already don't speak the language.
That's not even hitting on how he's effectively trapped the moment he got into Draculas carriage. The carriage switch was his last chance out.
Uh oh, fam. I don’t think Jonathan’s trip is going so well.

Impressions of Dracula Daily so far: 
They really do think everything east of Vienna is primitive and barbarian, don't they? 
Curious about the names he uses for the local populace. Some of them are familiar to me, others not. 
The descriptions of food are usually the best part of any travel narrative. 
Mamaliga lol. 
It's interesting how much he resembles a modern tourist seeking the "authentic, local" experience. 
The journey that is undertaken in stacking parts is one of the ideas I like to incorporate in my own (fantastical) narrative journeys. It's such an interesting way to emphasize the distance between two places, and how that didtance is partly created by access (or lack thereof).

Ok but what I also love about Dracula is him being like "I'm not like the cool kids I like DARKNESS and SHADOWS. I HATE mirth AND warmth. I like my buildings OLD and DILAPIDATED, thank you!" and my Johnathan not even thinking that is weird enough to comment upon he just like fucking accepts it.

I feel like it’s interesting that Dracula’s presenting himself as speaking poor English when he clearly speaks it well (according to Jon) and he’s talking all humbly about wanting to already be acclimated to English customs when he arrives in England. 
If I read this with the xenophobic lens I’m sure it was written with, it reads like, “This wicked foreign monster is trying to learn our ways so he can better infiltrate our land and destroy us.” And I’m sure that’s an theme here.
But if I read this from the perspective of Dracula, this feels like yet another manipulation tactic to get Jon’s guard down. He’s too old and powerful to not have at least some idea of what the English are like, plus he can absolutely pick up an idea of what they’re like and what they think of foreign cultures from the books he’s been reading (if he actually has been). What he’s doing here feels like he’s appealing to Jon’s national pride and innate sense of superiority for being English in order to lull him further into a false sense of security. He’s playing on that idea of “the white man’s burden,” the belief that white English folk have to set an example for the people they consider beneath them, in order to further persuade Jon that the peasants were wrong and just superstitious. 
And once again I think it’s interesting to realize that the narrative ends up framing Jon as being wrong for listening to that biased belief and going against whatever doubts he might have. While we shouldn’t ignore the bigotries that the book perpetuated, cultural hindsight and the knowledge of who Dracula is affords us the opportunity to read this as a sort of cautionary tale. It comes across as a warning that ignoring the red flags and trusting your biases over the knowledge of more experienced (but formally uneducated) people will put you in danger.

Dear Diary,
Seriously creepy stuff abounds.  My host has no reflection.  He cast my shaving mirror into the yawning chasm of jagged cliffside, rivers, and treetops below.  He recoiled from the crucifix that nice lady gave me (maybe catholics aren't so bad?) and became angry and ominous about the sight of blood when I nicked myself shaving.
I caught him making my bed and setting the table, so, yeah.  No servants, and I'm starting to think all these strange portents and his impassioned declarations (in the universal first person plural, no less) about local history might mean something ominous.
I'm so stressed I don't even remember what I ate for breakfast.
No one told me real estate law was going to involve something like this.  I wonder if it's too late to switch to something calmer, like taxes.
Love and kisses, ya boi, JHarks

tags: man the medievalist in me really got away with me this post
body:
oh boy, old johnny really is in it today in castle dracula
We don't see much historical context, but Jonathan does finally mention some of the gifts given to him by the coach passengers! "crucifix, garlic, wild rose, and mountain ash". The crucifix and garlic we of course understand (although it's more likely to be garlic blossoms, rather than the bulbs).
Wild rose I heard mentioned in a video essay on Dracula by Overly Sarcastic Productions. if their research is correct, it was believed that laying a wild rose on a vampire's coffin lid would prevent them from exiting the coffin come nightfall. Mountain ash, aka rowan, seems to have been associated with protection in general from a quick Google to check, especially from magic or enchantment.
Boyars have been mentioned before; the term is used a lot in Russia and Russia-adjacent countries in Eastern Europe. It seems to be about equivalent to a Duke/Duchess role, being second only to the ruling family.
Here, in the whirlpool of European races, the Ugric tribe bore down from Iceland the fighting spirit which Thor and Wodin gave them, which their Berserkers displayed to such fell intent on the seaboards of Europe, ay, and of Asia and Africa too, till the peoples thought that the were-wolves themselves had come.
The best guess I have at what the Count is referencing here is the general habit of Norse people, during the Viking age (~800s-1100s), of sailing down rivers to raid places. We know that by following the Volga down south Vikings reached the Black Sea, as far south as Constantinople (then capital of the Byzantine Empire), because we have records of Norse men serving as warriors in the 
Varangian guard
. The 
Kievan Rus
 were also active in Eastern Europe around the same time, pretty much through the extent of the Viking age, although I believe it's still debated whether they count as 'Vikings'. 
No idea why he specifies that they came from Iceland. While in the Icelandic sagas, heroes taking a break to go off east and do some raiding abroad is somewhat common, it's far more likely that anyone attacking Eastern Europe would be from Sweden, Norway, or Denmark (possibly also Finland, although with how borders were different back then and how Finns are referenced in Icelandic sagas, my main reference, I have no idea where the Finnish factor into things here). 
EDIT: Wodin is of course Odin; the W- spelling (Wodin or Woden) is more commonly found in Old English sources.
...they found the Huns, whose warlike fury had swept the earth like a living flame, till the dying peoples held that in their veins ran the blood of those old witches, who, expelled from Scythia had mated with the devils in the desert.
This is a complicated sentence full of commas, as literature of this period will do. I think Drac is saying the people being conquered by the Huns thought the Huns were descended from witches and devils, which, sure, why not. We've already had plenty of weird otherizing descriptions of other ethnicities. 
Attila the Hun ruled during the mid 400s, which means Drac is correct that the Huns were there long before the Vikings. No comments on the historical veracity of witches being expelled from Scythia.
Arpad
 is a historical person whose life seems to be hotly debated. Whatever the case, Dracula's assertion that he is Hungary's founder appears to agree with Hungarian sentiment (Hungarians, feel free to correct me if I'm wrong, I'm not really going farther than Wikipedia because I'm just having fun with this). "Honfoglalas" seems to be the Hungarian word for "the Hungarian conquest of the Carpathian basin", aka, the military action the Count is describing when he mentions Arpad.
and to us for centuries was trusted the guarding of the frontier of Turkey-land
I mentioned the Byzantine Empire earlier, and I'm going to take a stab that, since we're talking about medieval history still (9th century ish), Turkey-land is a reference to this Empire, since Constantinople, the imperial capital, was right at the gate between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea, and the Byzantines were largely occupying Greece and Turkey at this time. 
This link (
X
) is the only reference I could find with a quick search as to "the shame of Cassova". It seems that Cassova is a misspelled 'Kosovo'. As for the rest of this:
When was redeemed that great shame of my nation, the shame of Cassova, when the flags of the Wallach and the Magyar went down beneath the Crescent? Who was it but one of my own race who as Voivode crossed the Danube and beat the Turk on his own ground? This was a Dracula indeed!
'Voivode' seems to be a military/nobility title akin to a general, or more like a medieval lord leading his feudal serfs to battle. 
Drac's references to this noble Dracula who was betrayed by a brother seem to be references to the actual historical Vlad Dracul, aka the Impaler. I can't tell if it's just hard to do good research while eating breakfast and not giving it 100% of my attention, or if the problem is Stoker just saying whatever he wanted, but luckily I'm not the first person to write about 
the Dracula-irl Dracula links
. 
As a reminder, while I'm doing all this linking to Wikipedia and other non-academic sources, always fact check your research against other sources and make sure it's verifiable. Don't trust random people on the internet. If I were writing a thesis paper this would be completely unacceptable levels of research dedication. Luckily I am also a random person on the internet. 
We leave off with Jonathan referencing Arabian Nights, a rather famous story. In it, a woman, Scheherezade, is married to a king who kills his brides every morning after the day he marries them, so she tells him stories that end on a huge cliffhanger each dawn and refuses to continue until the next night. That way, he's too invested to kill her that day, and she has at least 12 more hours of being alive (and to think up an ending, and a new story to cliffhanger).

I just want everyone new to 
Dracula
 and reading 
Dracula Daily
 to note that you are getting to read this novel in a weird and wonderful way that its author absolutely did not intend. This is not a straight serialization of the text. Dates skip around in 
Dracula 
as it is written, moving the reader backwards and forwards in time to help shape the specific narrative Bram Stoker wanted to tell. We all will--in fact--be skipping ahead some chapters in a few days to meet another narrator only to skip immediately back to catch up with our collective friend Jonathan Harker.
And I think this is rad! I think it’s amazing to have a bunch of readers who are reading this book--not as Bram Stoker wrote it--but in a way that conforms to the steady march of events within it. This is a unique opportunity in that you guys don’t get to shape your reactions in relation to things you know will happen later. You can’t have your dread or anticipation undercut by future events.
Like all the characters you’re going to meet, you just have to wait for Dracula to act upon you.

Today’s most interesting facts from Klinger’s Annotated Dracula:
Dracula gets all the history wrong -- Klinger suggests that either he was trying to impress Harker without giving the truth away and so confusing details, or Harker misremembered what he said.
The idea that vampires are afraid of crucifixes comes from a 17th-century theological work by Leo Allatius, 
De Graecorum hodie quirundam opionationibus
 (On certain modern opinions among the Greeks) where he says that in the same way a witch requires the Devil, a witch, and the permission of God, so vampirism requires the Devil, a dead body, and the permission of God, and crucifixes, holy water, and the Eucharist revoke that permission.
There’s apparently a legend (and Klinger weirdly calls it “attributed to Mohammedans” rather than Muslims, wtf Klinger?) that “When Satan stepped out of the Garden of Eden after the fall of man, Garlick sprang up from the spot where he placed his left foot, and Onion from that where his right foot touched”.

body: one of my favorite things abt the beginning chapters of dracula is how jonathan is writing his diary, so he just will say all kinds of stuff super briefly about his own life and not think to elaborate on it because he already knows it, so we get our glimpses of who he is and where he’s from real sparingly as he’s thrown in media res into the experience of Being In Dracula. also how he name-drops mina ALL THE TIME but doesn’t actually say ‘my good friend and fiance, mina (who’s a teacher)’ so we learn about her in snippets of ‘mina would enjoy this chicken dish too’ and ‘mina probably wishes she could be road tripping through europe right now so he wants to make sure he brings back an accurate description to share it with her’ and ‘it looks like mina wants him to be confident in himself and his accomplishments, she wouldn’t be happy to hear him downplaying himself as just a clerk in his head’ so by the time we meet her and she’s this self-possessed, practical woman who would make the trek alone to find her disappeared fiance, and who is always lucy’s first and staunchest caretaker and defender, and who is so emotionally tough she resists a vampire’s mental thrall consistently enough to be instrumental in helping to locate and defeat him - well, we already know who she is, cause jonathan from our emails is so in love with her and has been quietly telling us all the while

This Is A Surprise Tool We Can Use Later

Alright, I can jump on this bandwagon:
I just subscribed to 
Dracula
 Daily.
I first read Dracula in high school, mostly as a protest against the then-popular Twilight novels. I stopped for a bit, then chose it as my English novel for my 12th grade summer homework.
Dracula is an amazing story, an epistolatory novel that thrives on dramatic irony for its tension and even real horror. No jump-scares, obviously, but a growing sense of dread as you figure out what’s going on only a couple of steps before the characters do, hoping desperately that they can catch up to you. 
And it is a thoroughly Christian novel. Dracula’s behavior is drawn heavily from Christian ideas of the mechanisms of sin, while the heroes combat their deathly enemy not only with Christian symbols, but with the three Christian theological virtues of faith, hope, and love.
There will be art, and maybe some literary analysis. But mostly, I’ll just be reading along with the rest of you out there in The Void. 
Let’s get spooky.

Okay, I had no idea what was going on with all the Dracula on my dash. I thought maybe there was a new show for it that I missed or something? But there weren't any gifs, so...
Anyway. Just figured out what is going on and I love this idea. 
Send me bits of the book in emails to read along with other people at the same time? Yes. Fantastic idea. 
Signed up.

Dracula Daily
Dracula Daily | DraculaDaily | Substack
"Bram Stoker’s 
Dracula
 is an epistolary novel - it’s made up of letters, diaries, telegrams, newspaper clippings - and every part of it has a date. The whole story happens between May 3 and November 10. So: 
Dracula Daily
 will post a newsletter each day that something happens to the characters, in the same timeline that it happens to them.
Now you can read the book via email, in small digestible chunks - as it happens to the characters."

In other news my heart goes out to folks who have, by circumstance or choice, not started Dracula Daily. I was there. It was terrible. 
I promise not to overwhelm anyone’s feed between now and November. You deserve that much and more.

body:
I had hung my shaving glass by the window, and was just beginning to shave. Suddenly I felt a hand on my shoulder, and heard the Count's voice saying to me, "Good-morning." I started, for it amazed me that I had not seen him, since the reflection of the glass covered the whole room behind me. In starting I had cut myself slightly, but did not notice it at the moment. Having answered the Count's salutation, I turned to the glass again to see how I had been mistaken. This time there could be no error, for the man was close to me, and I could see him over my shoulder.
Here's a question: why is Dracula sneaking up on Jonathan in his bedroom first thing in the 
morning
 evening?
Pretty sure he's been all politeness before, at least enough to knock. Is this a case of his getting tired of keeping up the pretense (he's still making beds and stuff later so that's iffy), or is he just having so much fun with Jonathan's obvious nervousness that he wants to have fun jump-scaring him?
It would be so funny if he saw the mirror and deliberately moved where he should've been reflected, as a kind of fun little prank, only to get startled into bloodlust when Jonathan cut himself.

I love reading old books because you feel this strange, wonderful connection to someone who lived so long ago and usually seems like just a historical fact or an image rather than a person. 
All this to say, like my buddy Jonathan Harker, I have also rushed to a train station half an hour early only for the train to peel out an hour after it was scheduled to leave.

BUT even though I am not even doing Dracula Daily I am positively GIDDY at the thought of Dracula being the new thing on tumblr, like obviously there has always been a not-insignificant percentage of Dracula fans on tumblr but now it’s THEE thing in the sense of multiple posts about it blowing up every day, what a time to be alive, this is what Dracula deserves and what we all deserve, can’t wait til we get to Lucy’s trio of vampire-fighting boyfriends.

I know we are all pins and needles waiting for the next dracula update but I for one am grateful to have the chance to catch up on dear johnathan's past emails.
He seemed so excited to try new foods when he left England!
I have subscribed to dracula daily! It's making me nostalgic for when I read Frankenstein in my senior year.

body: we need more daily epistolary emails of novels

I think the funniest possible modern textual adaptation of Dracula would be Jonathan as a part time recipe blogger and you have to scroll through 10 paragraphs of the most harrowing thing you’ve ever read in your life just to get the recipe for paprika hendl

Okay, as funny as Jonathan's obliviousness is, let us also remember one thing; He literally has no frame of reference here.
We know the castle is trouble, we've been conditioned to see it as trouble. But Jonathan is not only a man from a time when the English thought they had cracked every secret of the universe but also someone who does not know horror tropes. 
This is what makes Dracula such an interesting book. Because the heroes have to create monster-hunting strategies themselves and hope what Van Helsing knows is true.
There will be utterly hilarious moments due to this.

Hello everyone! While my name may be based in the realm of cosmic horror, my first love in the genre has always been the Gothic vampire story, so I'm super excited to see all this Dracula daily stuff going around.
I thought I'd take a moment to recommend one of my favorite vampire books, and favorite books in general. 
The Thief of Always by Clive Barker is a modern vampire story with a rather non-traditional take on the vampire as a monster. The short novel is targeted at all audiences, I first read it around 9 or 10, and 15 years later I still enjoy re-reading it. 
It does, to me, feel like a Gothic novel as far as narrative structure is concerned. It deals with the childhood wish for adult freedom, self discovery and expression, dealing with grief, loss, and regret, and love and human connection. All in all, it's a wonderful book that I think all fans of horror and the vampire should read at some point in their lives and that everyone can take something away from, and I feel like I don't see it referenced enough. 
If you get the chance, I hope you give it a read, and I hope you like it as much as I do.
Also, if you try to tell me Mr. Hood isn’t a vampire, I will fight you, and I will write an essay on why you are wrong.

You know what? I cannot WAIT until Tumblr discovers Mina Harker. And Quincey Morris.
Dracula is a good book actually and I feel like this website is going to really enjoy some bits of it. Like the shovel.

I think an interesting aspect of Dracula Daily that I hadn't considered before is how it not only has created a sort of bookclub-style community to discuss the book, it also has forced us all to live with the story in real time as opposed to reading as much as we want as often and as fast as we want. This isn't my first time reading Dracula, but this feels completely new all the same. That first day without an email actually had me thinking about the book throughout the day in a way that I wouldn't have been had I just read the book normally. I feel like I'm rambling, but it's just so cool!!!

Love how open-minded Jonathan is. He can't see his host's reflection in the mirror, gets lunged at when he cuts himself shaving, has his mirror yeeted out the fucking window, and told how dangerous it is around there. And he just goes downstairs and eats breakfast with only vague unease! King of embracing new cultures, change my mind.

body: As an English teacher, the absolute joy it brings me to see everyone reading Dracula Daily is so unreal. Dracula is genuinely such a fun book to read, with literally the most lovable cast of characters and equal levels of humour and tension. I usually hate 19c reading but this is one of my fave books and it's so wonderful to see a little bookclub together that may tackle some of the cultural capital in class- more students are likely to be familiar with the 19c style of writing that at least over here, examiners are obsessed with, and so will be able to prosper and thrive in a way I'm so excited to explore. Okay cool end of ramble.

Dracula Daily is actually amazing timing for me because this fall I'm taking a class on Gothic Horror Literature and one of the books we have to read is Dracula. It's also horrible timing because it means more likely than not I'm going to have to read ahead of the emails at some point. Anyways I hope my good friend Jonathan is doing okay on his trip!

body:
I could not help experiencing that chill which comes over one at the coming of the dawn, which is like, in its way, the turn of the tide. They say that people who are near death die generally at the change to the dawn or at the turn of the tide; any one who has when tired, and tied as it were to his post, experienced this change in the atmosphere can well believe it. 
i love death omens i LOVE death omens
Here's me voting for all of us to do a what we do in the shadows marathon on November 7th

On the Paprika thing: I’m kinda wondering if this could be evidence that Bram Stoker was allergic to paprika but didn’t realize because he just thought that was how paprika tasted. Because maybe it’s just me but unless it’s like a smoked paprika or something, paprika is kinda bland. Even the “spicy” stuff. But if it is overwhelming to Johnathan Harker and yet everyone around him doesn’t comment, I would hazard a guess that this reflects Bram Stoker’s experience with paprika. 
Kinda like those people who didn’t know they are allergic to pineapple and assumed it was supposed to make your mouth tingle and your lips burn.

body: Reading Dracula Daily at the same time as watching (the second season of) Russian Doll might have been a bit of a weird decision.

Ok but everyone collectively having a Dracula book club is perfectly timed because I literally just started coming up with a Dracula AU for Our Flag Means Death yesterday for reasons completely unrelated to Dracula daily. I was a little worried that I’d be the only one who actually has any interest in that sort of thing, but I guess I’m very wrong lol
Anyway, so here’s a basic outline of what I’ve got so far. If anyone wants to run with this and write their own fanfics or something, go ahead, just tag me so that I can read the hell out of it
 Blackbeard as Dracula because if you really think about it, their characters are EXTREMELY similar. In some of the more humanizing moments, Dracula laments that even if he knows how to speak English, that doesn’t mean that he’d actually fit in London, and that he’d still stick out like a sore thumb. Pretty much exactly like Blackbeard’s desire to fit in with the nobles in episode 5. Dracula isn’t even a name, it’s an epithet, and so you bet your ass I’m gonna run with the parallels to the Blackbeard title
 Stede as Jonathan because they’re both chronic dumbasses who have no idea what they’re doing and completely disregard the red flags that everyone around them have been begging them to look at. Also because it is my firm belief that Jonathan and Dracula should have kissed. 
 Mary as Mina. I love Mina Harker and don’t want to just dismiss her as “the female love interest”, and I think that Jonathan and Mina have a very sweet relationship, but in a theoretical Dracula AU fit, Mary makes the most sense as “woman who doesn’t hear from her fiancé for months before he finally gets found in a hospital in Budapest with PTSD”. If I do end up writing a full fan fiction, I’ll try to make sure that she isn’t just an obstacle to Blackstede and that she gets to have the cool moments that Mina has in the book
 Lucius as Lucy because they’re both polyamorous and they both get killed/almost killed by Dracula/Blackbeard. Also, someone on discord pointed out that their names are basically the same already
Jim as Van Helsing because the prospect of Jim as a vampire hunter who acts first and then explains nothing until the very last minute is perfect to me. Also, I’m pretty sure Van Helsing’s wife was killed by vampires, and that could easily translate into Jim having their family killed by vampires as a motivation.
 Oluwande as John Seward. This is something I still need to work on a bit since a large part of Seward’s character is that he’s in love with Lucy, but besides that, Seward is one of the few characters who actually has brain cells, and he’s also paired up with Van Helsing for most of the novel and since Jim is already filling that role, it makes sense to have Olu as their sidekick. 
 Black Pete as Arthur Holmwood just because he’s dating Lucius in the show and Arthur is boring enough that it’s very easy to copy and paste Black Pete in his place. 
 Dracula’s wives are Izzy, Ivan, and Fang, just because that’s Blackbeard’s crew. The wives aren’t really developed in the book so it’s very easy to just throw them in. I am also incredibly amused by the prospect of Izzy being Blackbeard’s malewife and getting scolded for almost eating Stede
 Buttons is Mr. Swales and I will not be taking any questions at this time. I’m correct.
That’s everything I have so far. I’m still trying to figure out who to cast as Quincey Morris, the third of Lucy’s suitors and resident cowboy. I’m tempted to throw in Calico Jack purely because of the cowboy vibes he gives off, but it doesn’t make much sense besides that. 
I do have an idea of what the story would look like, and I’m VERY excited because it’s surprisingly easy to tweak the story of Dracula to fit OFMD, but I don’t want to throw all of my ideas out here since I’m genuinely interested in seeing other people’s ideas of what this AU might look like

body:
So I took a class last year where one of the books we read was Dracula, and if you’re interested in analyzing the novel, here’s some themes we discussed:
- the fear of sex, and especially sexual deviancy - consider vampirism as a metaphor for sex (which is sometimes very explicit!), and consider the relationships between the characters
- modernity vs tradition: what is the place of traditions in the modern world? Can modern trappings truly eliminate the relevance of tradition and superstition? The English like to think of themselves as superior to regions and people with less industrialization and more superstition - how does this influence their problem solving?
- what it means to be Manly, and whether or not an Englishman of 1897, with all of his perceived civilization and culture, could embody that trait (contrast with Dracula (Romania) and Quincey (Texas))
- racism! antiromanism! do I even need to elaborate because it’s really obvious already!
- sexism! Personally I like to imagine how much shorter the novel would be if they’d just kept Lucy and Mina in the loop the whole time

body: We, collectively, as Jonathan Harker’s good friend he sends his letters to, should sit him down upon his return to London and stage a little intervention. The thing is, I’m just worried he’s too kind-hearted and needs to be told to look out for himself more. I know he just recently passed his exam and is probably still in a trainee mindset, but I think we should really tell him that he doesn’t need to play substitute teacher to rich clients or stay awake the entire night just because they want to chat. No matter how charming he thinks the client in question is. He’s not getting additional compensation for any of that. He deserves respect, rest and a quick business transaction handled professionally from both sides, without any exploitation. And it’s time he learns to value himself and his time in that way.

(vague Dracula spoilers maybe? my take on what's going on with the blue lights)
In order to give some Actual Commentary: I think the blue light from the May 5 entry aren't actually about buried treasure at all, althought that could be one of the legends about them. They're will o' the wisp, most probably, and serve to mark the road to the castle for Dracula during this one night in which it's possible for him to traverse the barrier between the living and the dead with a full on coach with an actual living person on it (did you think it was a coincidence that Harker was scheduled to arrive specifically *that night*?). The coachman was Dracula himself and the one hour round trip he forced poor Harker to take was about going across some sort of barrier that surrounds his castle without arousing *too much* suspicion. Like he could've easily idk bewitched Jonathan and dragged him back to the castle as prey but he *really really* wants all of his documents about his trip to England to be in order and he needs a British lawyer in full possession of his abilities to do that. Dracula just gives the buried treasure story as he knows it sounds compelling. 
I should add I haven't read the book in a long while + Stoker never gives like...a detailed lore breakdown IIRC, which I think makes the book more charming, but also means that sometimes we can only guess at what's going on. It is supposed to be strange, after all.

I have received several days' entries of my dear friend Jonathan’s journal, in his most familiar shorthand. He has arrived in foreign lands, and has written in lush detail of his travels so far, both of the land itself and the peoples therein. I have found his descriptions of the food there most tantalizing, and amusing that he had so much trouble with it and yet, he makes note to remember to fetch the recipes to bring home to his beloved Mina still. (Ah Mina, I should write to her soon. It has been far too long!) The castle that was his destination is most interesting, and I cannot wait to hear more about his stay, and the peculiar master of it. I shan't write back to him at this time, as he will surely be on his way back before any such letter would reach him.

body:
Our Victorian himbo has difficulties adjusting to the new sleep schedule and is FINALLY becoming aware of what he's gotten into when the Count fails to gain any reflection on himself (behold that pun) and goes through the 
horny
 bloodlust of his life when Jonathan cuts himself during shaving. He's calmed down by the power of vicarious Christianity, and I still think Bram Stoker can't tell a rosary from a crucifix necklace. Despite this little incident and feeling increasingly unsettled by Dracula's presence (and annoyed because the latter broke his shaving glass - priorities, man! Get them!), Jonathan is miffed that he's left alone for a meal, and then 
very
 unsettled when he finds he can't leave the castle because Dracula is developing Overly Attached Boyfriend syndrome. 
I'm pleasantly surprised that it actually 
is
 Dracula playing servant, making Jonathan's bed and whatnot; we know there are ladies in this house and it's the 1890s, so I appreciate a man who'll willingly do chores. Jonathan tries to be subtle and suave when talking to Dracula. Amazingly, it works; Dracula gets into a rant about his family history which reads like Stoker is being contemptuous of other cultures and ethnicities again. Trying to make Dracula look snooty because he looks down on "peasants" is kinda rich tho when compared with Jonathan's attitude during the first chapters. Stoker is also trying to namedrop every ethnic group and noble family he knows, plus literary references to 1001 nights and Hamlet, so we can rest assured he's well-educated. Not buying it; that history bit smells fishy. 
Wonder if Jonathan's casual attitude is healthy. He's like, "yeah, I realized I'm being held prisoner, talked a bit to my captor, then went to bed (to enjoy queer dreams)". Dissonant much?

Way back in 1992 I was grumpy at the casting of Keanu Reeves as Jonathan Harker.  He was fresh from Bill and Ted, and his performance vacillated wildly between stilted and slack-jawed.
But now re-reading Mr Harker going from ‘I fear I am myself the only living soul within the place’ to ‘He must be a very peculiar man!’ in the space of five minutes, I am more forgiving.  Jonathan Harker is an uptight British dumbass, and Mr Reeves was performing him very faithfully.

They say that people who are near death die generally at the change to the dawn or at the turn of the tide; any one who has when tired, and tied as it were to his post, experienced this change in the atmosphere can well believe it."

tags: truly there is nothing new under the sun
body:
Bless that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it. It is odd that a thing which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my mind about it.
Interesting that in the codifier for modern vampire fiction we 
already
 have a character wondering why it is that crosses (or crucifixes, rather) repel vampires even when your faith doesn't hold them sacred.

Can someone please explain dracula daily to me. You guys seem like you're having so much fun and i don't know what's going on.

So I saw a few different posts about the type of paprika that would have been used in the paprika hendl that Jonathan Harker ate on May 3 that didn’t match my experience with chicken paprikash or with Hungarian paprika. 
Obviously actual Hungarians know their own spices best, but I wondered if maybe there was a translation thing happening, or a difference in nomenclature. 
Or even just an assumption that Americans on tumblr only use generic paprika, which isn’t true for me. 
It got me curious, and I went down a bit of a rabbit hole. 
This is what I’ve come up with:
There are multiple types of Hungarian paprika, all of which are different from the adjectiveless generic paprika that is found in American  grocery stores.
All Hungarian paprika will be 
“deeper and more complex”
 than generic paprika. Stronger, too, I’d wager.
However, Hungarian paprikas 
vary
 
in how
 
hot they are
, 
as well as 
other flavor profile qualities, depending on the variety. 
The two main types, per the sources I found, are Hot (csipős) and Sweet (édes). 
The sweet paprika is not actually sweet, especially to an American palate, but that’s what it’s called in English. 


 In the US, both are available in grocery stores as Hot and Sweet Hungarian paprika, respectively. I have a tin of Pride of Szeged sweet paprika in my spice cabinet. 
Per the same sources, the type of Hungarian paprika used for paprika hendl (chicken paprikash) is the sweet. 
So the Hungarian sweet paprika used in chicken hendl is hotter and more complexly flavored than what you’re used to if you’re used to generic paprika. 
And it’s definitely hotter and more complex than 1890s Englishman Jonathan Harker would have been used to, or even really familiar with.
And, of course, the question of what the Hungarian sweet paprika used in that area of Transylvania in the 1890s would have tasted like in comparison with the Hungarian sweet paprika available today (both in and out of Hungary) is another question, and one that I cannot speak to at all. 
 But if you use Hungarian sweet paprika regularly, as I do, and/or have eaten or cooked chicken paprikash, and were confused by references in tumblr posts to the use of hot paprika to make it, there’s your answer.
(I only linked each source once, though each spoke to everything that I mentioned.)

Thinking about the may 6th entry and how in my mind dracula stopped now and then leaving (as a coach driver) his guest alone with howling wolves to fly as a bat or sth with wings to his castle to check (as a chef) on his roast in the oven, preparing the bedchambers (as a housekeeper), for his guest who will at the end of the trip receive as the castle owner. You can already clearly see he was alive too damn long.

The novel opens with a train schedule complaint and we have gotten to the point where Count Dracula, the most iconic vampire of all time, is chilling in his Anglophile library reading a book that is nothing but page after page of English railway times. I want everyone new to this to know that this is just the beginning. This will not stop. We cannot get off the train of train allusions that we are on now.

The sum up 5th may of Jonathan Harker' letter:
The people are really nice but wierd. They actively tried to make him miss his meeting with the counts coach in some misguided attempt to keep him safe. He had the worst night drive ever to the point where if it was an option he'd have pitched himself out and run. His driver was creepy on several different levels. Count Dracula house was dope. The cab driver could kill him if he wanted. He was absolutely prepared to stand outside and wait till morning because banging on the door with a fist was too rude I guess. Had a moment of absolute relief when he got to bathe and had food, thinking that things were funny making sense again. Only for his host to turn out to be really creepy. Halp.

So, an interesting thing I’ve noticed about reading Dracula is that, if I didn’t already know what Dracula was about, up until the point where Jonathan reaches Dracula’s place, I would have assumed the twist/source of horror in the story would turn out to be. Like. A religious cult in the area or something. 
You know, people doing horrible things in the name of god, or worshiping something that turns out not to be god, or whatever.
I mean, obviously there’s the crucifixes and the warding gestures (and Jonathan even reflects on the cross feeling idolatrous, which feels like foreshadowing), but there’s also stuff like the people praying to roadside altars in the mountains.
Like, pretending I don’t know what’s going to happen lets my mind go in different directions; I imagine if I had actually read it without knowing the plot, I would have had a lot of fun getting my expectations subverted.

body:
Dracula Daily is living proof that people crave regular serialized content and not just binging.
A 125 years old novel you could get for free and read in one sitting gained a new thriving fandom because somebody turned it into a serialized series.
Take notes, streaming services.
Maybe you’ll get more mileage out of your shows if you didn’t unceremoniously dump entire seasons all at once.
Love getting a message from my buddy Jonathan Harker on my birthday <3

I think what I love most about Jonathan Harker is that it’s not that he’s oblivious to or ignoring the danger, it’s that he’s still preoccupied with day to day life in the midst of it. 
His entries are like:
“Dear trustworthy travel journal. The conviction that my life is in deadly peril grows stronger on me moment by moment. More strange and threatening things happened today. First the Count came up behind me while I was shaving and I saw without doubt that he had no reflection in the glass! This startled me so much that I cut myself. On seeing the blood, the Count lunged for my throat like a wild animal, but was turned back by the crucifix around my neck and acted like nothing had happened.
“Then he threw my shaving mirror out of the window. How am I going to shave now! I’ll have to peer at my reflection in the metal bottom of the shaving cream pot. Most annoying!
“Anyway, after that I took up the Count’s invitation to explore the castle and learned that all the rooms and corridors leading to exterior doors are locked and confirmed that there are no servants in the house. Either I’m going mad and imagining dangers that do not exist, or the chances of me getting out of here alive are slim.
“That’s all for now!”
Like, big two years of pandemic mood.

body:
Okay so whilst I'm happy that people are now discovering the absolute 
brilliance
 that is Dracula, it does kinda make me wanna be selfish a little bit. Like, here's this small-ish fandom that I like to check up on from time to time, and there's not too much fan stuff, bit it's great and I love it and OOP- wait, wtf, why's it 
trending
...? Three days later it's still trending, even moreso, and now everyone's talking about it. I mean, on the one hand it's great (fan theories and headcanons and y'all's delicious fanart 🤌), but on the other hand it's like, wait, no, give me my small little community back, 
I beg of you don't yassify Jonathan-- (〒﹏〒)

I love how it seems to be a universal foreigner thing where they’ll have absolutely impeccable English, in some cases surpassing that of native speakers, but will still be like “Yeah sry my English sucks.” (I beta’ed a fic for a friend who is ESL and looked up incredibly archaic words nobody in modern English actually uses and was like “How the fuck did you find these?”)
“Of course you’re not going to want to go where the doors are locked, because you know I’ve locked them for a reason. Right? Right??”
lol Carfax
on the “
kodak
” mentioned in the description of the property. It is indeed a camera (I guess the same way we would use Kleenex as a generic term for tissue even though it is a brand name), which was pretty new technology at the time.
Because the book is so old, it’s strange to think about it in its contemporary context as a novel about modernity butting up against the traditional. Like if you suddenly went back and Poe or Mary Shelley are explicating the world in the manner of William Gibson. That’s fucking cool.
In conclusion, Jonathan is by no means unaware of his impending doom but he IS easily distracted from it, which is funnier.

body:
Y'all don't seem to realize that Jonathan Harker's not a real estate agent, he's a 
lawyer. 
He just passed the bar exam (or whatever the 1897 British version of that is) before leaving London for this trip. He's a real estate lawyer and all his documents are legal documents!
So we're not reading about our good buddy Johnny the realtor, he's our good buddy Johnny the newly certified lawyer who's book-smart but not very worldly as he travels to Transylvania to explain British property laws to his client, Count Dracula.

It’s such a trip to start a dedicated 
Dracula 
blog, to use the obsessive interest in the novel that I cultivate there to leverage my way into graduate school, to take some time away from said blog as life events and shifts in academic work drive me to other pursuits, and then--nearly 
ten whole years 
after I started--to return to find tumblr undertaking a mass reread of the book just as I’m entering the final year of my dissertation work.
This is such a wild time for me. I’m so glad to come back and find so many enthusiastic readers just... here. Gosh.

body:
it's a bit wild following along with the dracula daily community as someone who's read the book several years ago; I remember a lot of the story beats and minor details, but not all of them, and I could go flip through my copy again to refresh myself but that feels like cheating. also, there's the creeping feeling of watching people react to the story in real time, people who are aware of dracula generally but have no idea what's coming next. it's actually giving me an entirely new appreciation for the horror of the story, in a way I never really got when reading the book for myself.
idk, it's fascinating. I'm really enjoying this experience so far.

7 May
My Dear Mr. Harker, 
Though our friendship is but new, I do hope you will forgive my coarseness when I ask you, "What in the name of sweet Jesus Christ is your problem?" 
Begging your forgiveness, I continue my letters. 
I see you have noticed the strangeness of the good Count's castle, especially the lack of mirrors and all the locked doors, and the apparent lack of servants. Dear friend, before any further oddness befalls you, I encourage you to quickly depart from the castle and return to the village, making only the most necessary trips and conducting the remainder of your business through the local post. 
I should like to hear from you soon, and know that you are well. 
With all my friendship, 
Me

Just before I was leaving, the old lady came up to my room and said in a very hysterical way:
“Must you go? Oh! Young Herr, must you go?” She was in such an excited state that she seemed to have lost her grip of what German she knew. When I told her I must go at once, she asked again:
“Do you know what day it is?” I answered that it was the fourth of May. She shook her head as she said it again:
“Oh, yes! I know that! I know that, but do you know what day it is?” On my saying that I did not understand, she went on:
“It is Star Wars Day. Do you not know that to-day, all the evil things in the world have full sway? Do you know where you are going, and what you are going to?” She was in such evident distress that I tried to comfort her, but without effect. Finally she went down on her knees and implored me not to go; at least to wait a day or two before starting. It was all very ridiculous but I did not feel comfortable. I raised her up, and said, as gravely as I could, that I thanked her, but my duty was imperative, and that I must go. She then rose and dried her eyes, and taking an led light-saber key chain from her neck offered it to me. I did not know what to do, for, as a Trekkie, I have been taught to regard such things as in some measure idolatrous, and yet it seemed so ungracious to refuse an old lady meaning so well and in such a state of mind. She saw, I suppose, the doubt in my face, for she put the light-saber key chain in my pocket, and said, “May the Fourth be with you,” and went out of the room. I am writing up this part of the diary whilst I am waiting for the coach, which is, of course, late...

body:
I do feel for Jonathan Harker. This is his first job with his official grown up lawyer license! Maybe this is just what's supposed to happen! Is this what business trips are like? He doesn't know! 
Maybe that's just how that works in Transylvania! Shit's weird out here! They put paprika on the chicken! PAPRIKA! Jonathan is a nineteenth century Englishman! This may be his first time encountering A Seasoning. He was physically and emotionally unprepared for paprika on chicken. 
He thought he was prepared, he tried to be prepared. He spent a whole afternoon in the british library looking at maps and thought he was totally prepared but the maps didn't say anything about paprika on chicken. And what else didn't the maps tell him? Maybe this other shit is all completely normal in the land of paprika chicken! Maybe the peasants give free crucifixes to everybody! Maybe all the ominous muttering about the devil is a standard form of small talk! Maybe all Romanian coachmen can control wolves! WHO KNOWS? NOT JONATHAN!

body: Everyone's reading Dracula together, it's like in highschool when you come in every lesson having read a couple more chapters in whatever assigned book and you all sit there having discussions like what the fuck are we all reading? That's what Dracula daily is doing. And I think it's lovely.

body:
YES Harker is a sweet little nerd happy to see his little law books in Dracula's library
BUT ALSO bear in mind that our boy is having a Weird Time.  He's been transported to a strange and terrifying world full of rosaries and wolves and blue fire and paprika and is living with a dude who has neither mirrors nor doorknobs nor any visible servants but 
does
 have terrible breath and sharpened fingernails.  Seeing something solid and real and familiar must be a huge relief - a connection, lifeline even, to his rational 
normal
 life.  
So much of 
Dracula
 is about the tension between the safe modern rational world and this ancient mystical Gothic horror.  Is it any wonder that Jonathan "too English for this" Harker is comforted by this tangible connection back to home, England, the areas of his own expertise?  For the first time, he's not completely out of his depth.
And lbr, there is nothing 
less
 mystical than law lists.

‘every sign imaginable points towards my host being extremely shady! BUT he has perfectly internalized the truth of his cultural inferiority and yearns for nothing more than being deemed acceptable by the civilized people of my country, so everything must be ok!’

Oh so the "its fighting done by fools and its learning done by cowards, you my good sir are both a coward and a fool" dude was referencing Dracula?

As someone who has spent three years of my life obsessing over Dracula, I nearly had a stroke when I saw it trending just because everyone is doing the Dracula Daily thing.
Anyway, I hope this means that more people will actually know what happens in that book now because it features iconic moments such as:
 Dracula practically having a love confession for Jonathan and then carrying him to bed and folding his clothes after he passes out. That’s real, it happened, and it’s been haunting me ever since.
 Everyone thinks of Dracula as a spooky vampire man, and he is, but he’s also the physical embodiment of mansplain, manipulate, malewife and the fact that all three of those descriptors can be supported with textual evidence is both amusing and distressing to me
 Quincey Morris has the funniest proposal speech ever and I take every opportunity to quote it
 Everything Van Helsing ever says is insane and I need y’all to know that before you think that he’s some badass vampire hunter. He is, but he also refuses to explain anything to anyone ever
 Also, Seward and Van Helsing find a kid in the middle of the night while doing vampire business and instead of handing them over to the authorities, since that would require them to explain what they were doing and how they found a child in the middle of the night, they wait until they see a police officer approaching and then leave the kid in the middle of the sidewalk for the officer to see. I can’t believe that this happens in a scary gothic horror novel 
 While discussing vampire business, Quincey just kinda… gets up and leaves, and then suddenly everyone hears a gunshot and they look out to see Quincey who was like “yeah I saw a bat, I’ve just been shooting any bat I see nowadays”. 
 Quincey is generally just the best character ever because his one personality trait is Texas. And I know that because if you’re like me and read Bram Stoker’s notes, he’s literally just referred to as The Texan for a while. 
Anyway, all of that is just off the top of my head, I’m sure I’ll think of more later. I just wanted to build some hype so that people actually read this book

body: I love how the crow of a cock usually marks the end of a horror story, but for Jonathan it marks the end of sanity. Like, he while he is pretty much a dead man from the moment he stepped foot in the carriage, he still hasn’t fully gasped what’s happening to him.  And now he muses about people near death dying at the change of dawn. It’s the last time he is going fall asleep with an easy mind. The morning has not arrived to save him, but he doesn’t know it yet and that makes everything even more tragic.

I feel like everyone new to reading 
Dracula
 this year would probably benefit from knowing that in the original outline, Jonathan at the beginning of the novel was already supposed to have undergone the events in “Dracula’s Guest” where he spent Walpurgisnacht wandering around in a storm and watching a hot vampire lady get struck by lightning before a wolf-that-was-probably-Dracula came and sat on him to keep him warm all night.
I feel like this missing bit of information goes a long way to explaining why he’s sort of like: “Storm. Wolves. Mysterious blue flames my preternaturally strong driver gets out to inspect. Is this a normal part of being a solicitor? (
Mem.
 Remember not to call yourself a clerk. Mina will be proud of you. <3)”
