I love how the unequivocal proof of impending doom for our dear friend Jonathan was the ominous sight of The Prince of Darkness discreetly making his bed, like “I can understand taking me on disorienting night rides, having superhuman strength, controlling wolves, not showing in mirrors and jumping at throats but secretly being the maid?! I'm definitely going to die”
Finding out Dracula has a mustache delivered psychic damage I was not remotely prepared for

Jonathan Harker is a guy who doesn’t want to blow his new promotion and so is willing to ignore a few red flags.
He’s also a guy who is very English and sees the superstitions as just that. He only takes the crucifix from the lady because it would be rude not to.
And because we the reader know that Count Dracula is Bad News™ and the real reason he doesn’t eat supper with Jonathan, his real reason he doesn’t travel (hint: it ain’t due to gout), and ‘doesn’t drink wine’ we are in on the dramatic irony that Jonathan doesn’t know what genre he’s stumbled himself into.
He doesn’t know he’s in a story, he’s over here writing a food and travel blog as a side thing to do while having to travel for business anyway. And honestly whomst amongst us wouldn’t do the same given the opportunity?

body: Anyone else not get their Dracula daily email today it just me?

Dracula talking about wanting to practice his English is exactly what my Taiwanese mom says to everyone she talks to even though she’s been speaking English for longer than I’ve been alive by quite a few years (about 50 or so years).
Part of it is a sort of icebreaker, if people think they’re teaching you or helping you they’re going to open up to you faster. My mom has a gift of gab and can have someone go from complete stranger to telling her their life story in the span of 15 minutes. 
Another part is being self conscious of her accent, which to her defense has made telemarketers and other people calling on the phone think they’re speaking to a child. Commonly my mom would then hand the phone to me out of sheer frustration. She’s 70 years old and they’re asking to speak to her mother. 
Dracula may have been studying English for as long (or perhaps longer, being as he is an immortal vampire) than my mother and he is still self conscious of how he’ll sound to a native speaker. Which is sort of adorable.

May 3 starts out interestingly enough. Mr. Johnathan is on his way to Transylvania to visit count dracula. I find the part about the Szekelys descended from the Huns interesting. Szekelys are Hungarians, apparently (Johnathan mentions he’s going to pass through that area.) 
The book is set in Romania, where Transylvania is located. A mountain range goes through Transylvania, the Carpathian mountains. Slovakia is just above Romania, so he’s traveling southeast. He describes the Slovaks as wearing cowboy like attire, except they have long black hair.
He enters Bizistra. Count dracula directs him to a hotel there. He’s to set off the next day towards Bukovina, with the next destination being a pass to Transylvania.
Just some basic setting stuff I didn’t really think about the first time I read the book. looking up maps of Romania is helpful here.

body:
So thrilled to see the hype for the original Dracula
My only fandoms are the super dormant ones about old books so it’s really fun to see the ORIGINAL version of Dracula come to life online, here on Tumblr!! 
I’m really hoping y’all get to enjoy the book as it unfolds, and understand why Mina was so misunderstood as a character in nearly all adaptations. There’s so much complexity/weirdness in Stoker’s book to be appreciated that hardly ever pops up in other media.
-- if any of you want to read more vampire stuff and gothic fiction from that same century, let me know!! I did so much research on vampires in literature and the gothic genre when I was writing The Carpet Merchant @_@
Well I personally am very happy to read that the count is taking care of my good friend Jonathan Harker. I do hope nothing goes amiss in that castle.

I just realized that Dracula Daily is a perfect encapsulation of why VIP systems—seeing the finale early on iQiyi, getting books a month early in Choices, etc—in media are such a bad idea from a fandom perspective. Fandom isn't created by exclusivity, it's created by everyone being on the same part of the story together and the feeling of journeying through it. I mean, the book is in the public domain and just about every library, you could easily get it and read ahead. But there's a sense of community in reading about Jonathan Harker reaching the castle and then coming on here to see people talking about that very thing.
When you sell early access to media, it creates a desynchronization within the community. People who buy early access can't talk about it for fear of posting spoilers, and people who don't can't go into those spaces for fear of seeing spoilers. Even if you use the appropriate tags and blacklist the appropriate spoilers, it creates a fission in the fandom. The theory someone posted about the newest episode is already outdated by 10 episodes. That amazing artist's fanart is completely inaccessible until you either wait out the public release or cave and shell out. At best, it leads to confusion and frustration (as with many iQiyi shows as they approach the finale). At worst, it leads to a complete desiccation of an exhausted community (as with Choices).

tags: the indignation about public transport is real
body:
I’m on May 5th and lost about half an hour on researching train schedules from Munich to Vienna cause I couldn’t believe it took my darling friend Jonathan Harker 10 hours and 11 minutes to go from one place to the other; surely there is a quicker way?
Does NOT help that these days it’s barely 5 hours; depending on when one chooses to take the train, understandably. If he’d taken the train at 8.17 nowadays, that one would’ve only taken him 4 hours 20... but of course, the later trains all take at least 6, if not 7 hours+

you: looking at myself in the mirror
me, an intellectual: Pondering my foul bauble of man's vanity

Within, stood a tall old man, clean shaven save for a long white moustache, and clad in black from head to foot, without a single speck of colour about him anywhere.
It has been a while since I've read 
Dracula
, but I can't believe I forgot he was rocking a mustache.
"Welcome to my house! Enter freely and of your own will!" He made no motion of stepping to meet me, but stood like a statue, as though his gesture of welcome had fixed him into stone. The instant, however, that I had stepped over the threshold, he moved impulsively forward....
Also, how did this bit of lore get dropped?  I get that it means you can't have a vampire kidnapping people and bringing them back to its lair, but I like this.  It's faerie-level binding courtesy.

tags: if you aren’t doing dracula daily
body: Reading Dracula must have hit a lot differently when it first came out.

Everybody subscribed to Dracula Daily is giving Jonathan such a hard time for not figuring out something is sketchy with Dracula. But like — what is he supposed to do about it? He’s in a castle in the middle of nowhere! It took forever to get here in a coach (which he doesn’t have access to) and Dracula is the only person here! He’s supposed to what, wander the wilderness trying to escape? He was chased by wolves on the way there! He can’t walk away! He’s just trying to do his job and hope things will work out because what else is there.

I signed up for Dracula Daily last night and honestly this was the best (Tumblr peer pressured) thing I've ever done. 
Looking forwards to reading this without the pressure of analysing it to death.

body:
Hitherto I had noticed the backs of his hands as they lay on his knees in the firelight, and they had seemed rather white and fine; but seeing them now close to me, I could not but notice that they were rather coarse—broad, with squat fingers. Strange to say, there were hairs in the centre of the palm. The nails were long and fine, and cut to a sharp point. As the Count leaned over me and his hands touched me, I could not repress a shudder. It may have been that his breath was rank, but a horrible feeling of nausea came over me, which, do what I would, I could not conceal. The Count, evidently noticing it, drew back; and with a grim sort of smile, which showed more than he had yet done his protuberant teeth, sat himself down again on his own side of the fireplace.
Jonathan Harker, May 5

body:
I hope we all enjoyed receiving our first letter from our friend Jonathan!
If you're reading Dracula for the first time I will say that I personally find the short lead up before Jonathan reaches his first destination to be the trickiest part of the novel to get through, I promise it gets more interesting !
I'm already feeling soft about Jonathan wanting to get recipes because he thinks Mina will like them.
disheartened to hear that he couldn't sleep well because of "all sorts of queer dreams", we've all been there....
Oh! And so lovely that his friend Dracula is inquiring of him and sending him well wishes!

I think the most tragic thing about reading this like a hundred years later is that it has become nothing short of a Himbo Blorbo comedy.
Which is also a good thing.
I have been reminded why Jonathan Harker is my very best friend. I cannot wait to see my other very best friends too.

Hey all! After looking at all the hype about Dracula Daily, I thought to myself, why not do this with other epistolary novels? So I took it upon myself to do this with another novel, one of my favorites: The Sorrows of Young Werther by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, 1774 translated from German.
Just like Dracula Daily, the day's occurance will be posted. It is worth noting that I missed the very first entry, and so today you will have to imagine that it is May 4. Also- I will not check for any mistakes or such, and if you have any requests for formatting or such then ask and ye shall receive (perhaps). The book ends at around Christmas (the year after, so christmas 2023 teehee), so I'll stick around till then. Spreading the word is very much appreciated.
Also: Block the tag 'interruption' if you don't want updates or whatever

FOR THOSE OF Y’ALL INTERESTED IN READING ACCOUNTS OF VLAD DRACULA WRITTEN A FEW DECADES AFTER HIS DEATH… 
READ A MANUSCRIPT WRITTEN BY THE MONK EFROSIN HERE
SOURCES FROM THE GLOBAL MEDIEVAL SOURCEBOOK HERE

body: "I did not sleep well, though my bed was comfortable enough, for I had all sorts of queer dreams." lol. lmao.

Dracula
by Bram Stoker
What’s it about?
It’s about pre-Brexit Britain, when an unemployed violent criminal from Eastern Europe could just wander into Whitby, Yorkshire and the predictable chaos he causes before, during and after the journey. 
This is nothing like the movies.
No, it’s not. Modern readers will be confronted with a book made up of letters between the characters, diary entries and the occasional news clipping for context. 
Wait. When is this bit happening? Did we go back?
The narrative skips around a bit. Don’t worry about it. It all comes together. Well, it doesn’t, but it’s fine (because it serves the narrative) and anyway, if you’ve read 
Game of Thrones
 and you can’t handle a bit of skipping around then you should present yourself to relevant authorities at first light. 
Wait. Is this a sex thing? 
We’ve all been conditioned by movie adaptations who are motivated to push the sexy angle, so probably not. There’s no way to be entirely sure but it’s worth pointing out that it certainly works as a sex metaphor. 
And?
And it works as a metaphor for disease. So, no connection there, then. And certainly no explanation for the sudden explosion of vampire movies in the mid-1980s.
Wait. Is this a feminist thing?
Probably not. But it’s worth pointing out that most of the vampires in the book are women and they all aggressively pursue male victims.
What should I say to make people think I’ve read it?
“Real estate deals never go according to plan.”
What should I avoid saying when trying to convince people I’ve read it?
“My favourite Dracula is Tom Cruise.”
Should I actually read it?
Yes. It’s lots of fun. Just don’t expect a movie script.

Love how Dracula just walks into Jonathan's room completely uninvited and proceeds to throw his mirror out the window and calls it "a foul bauble of man's vanity" after it exposes the Count as not having any reflection and Jonathan is just like dude. I was shaving with that.
And the fact that Jonathan spent the afternoon in a terror, feeling like a rat in a trap, but was at least a little mollified by Dracula's weirdly first-hand accounts of his family's extremely violent and bloody history.
I'm also loving the visual of Dracula making the bed. One of the most iconic horror monsters in modern history, has killed untold numbers of people, sneaking into someone's room to make the bed. Incredible.

body:
Friends, we have reached the point in our communal 
Dracula
 journey where I invite you to join me in one of my favorite thought experiments:
How did Dracula learn to cook?
He is a nobleman!  There is no way he cooked his own meals while he was alive!  And now, he famously neither eats nor drinks, yet he’s able to produce “an excellent roast chicken.”  I want to see how he got to that point.
Just imagine this aged, dignified vampire suddenly realizing that he is going to
 
have to 
feed his human guest
 and rushing frantically to the kitchen to try to figure out how to use it.  How many chickens did he destroy in his culinary training montage?  Can he cook anything else?  Does Dracula know how to bake?
Please join me in picturing Dracula, in his stark black clothes and his long white moustache, absolutely 
covered
 in flour, staring into a mixing bowl in rage and despair.  It’s my favorite thing.

The Count: 
*no reflection, man handles me at the sight of blood, flies into a demonic fury, smashes my razor, gets burned by a crucifix* 
Jonathan: Haha annoying! Guess I’m gonna have to get creative if I’m gonna be here a while!
The Count: 
*doesnt eat breakfast*
Jonathan: Come to think of it… there’s something really off about this guy…
Smh, typical English protestant behavior to go head first into supernatural shit despite knowing that the vibes are off

Sweet pepper / bell pepper / capsicum / paprika / sweet paprika / peperone / pimiento morrón / poivron - however you call your spice and heat free peppers. They didn't exist until the 1920s. (Thank you for the delicious cultivar farmers of Szeged, Hungary)
Dracula was published in 1897
Tumblr's current sweet of heart and dumb of ass babygirl Jonathan Harker merrily destroys himself with hot, hot paprika. He is chugging pitchers of water while politely asking hotel cooks for their delicious recipes, he is having capsaicin induced queer fever dreams, and he is going straight downstairs in the morning to chomp on even more hot peppers as he sets off to meet his good friend Count Dracula
I relate to Jonathan Harker bc I too would forget my uneasiness if Count Dracula let me read my boss' kinda gay letter of recommendation praising me.

body:
absolutely wild trying to get in the mindset of someone reading dracula around the time it came out, before it was so embedded in popular culture that everyone knows the gist of what’s to come
it just clicked with me that at this point in the novel you are 100% supposed to either think count dracula is a werewolf or not be entirely certain which he is. obviously there is something fuckin weird about this guy but there are a 
lot
 of signs at this point in the book pointing towards him being a werewolf, and most of the signs of vampirism right now are more ambiguous if you don’t already know he is one
the word used in the rumors is ambiguous - jonathan states it can describe someone who is a vampire or a werewolf
the scene in which dracula’s driver seems to instantly deal with a bunch of wolves, and dracula’s later comment about loving the sound of wolf howls
dracula references being a hunter - this could go either way
dracula’s pointed ears and sharp teeth could also go either way. they’re typically vampiric traits but would also give him a wolfish appearance
care is taken to describe dracula’s hair as plentiful, thick, and curly - the comment about hair on his palms really stands out as something meant to make you think he may be a werewolf
the fact that dracula says he already ate - is he lying because he doesn’t eat food, or has he already done his hunting for the night, seeing as it’s so late?
the surprising strength of both dracula’s driver and dracula himself are another ambiguous hint towards Something - both vampires and werewolves are often described as being extremely strong
there are some things (dracula’s deathly pallor and cold hands, the noticeably red lips on his driver, the fact that he appears both old and surprisingly vivacious) that point more heavily towards “vampire” but it definitely feels like stoker was purposely muddying the information so you know there is 
something
 up with dracula but you can’t be entirely sure what
this also means you don’t know what specific actions jonathan should be wary of, or how he ought to defend himself! werewolves and vampires are two very different types of threat, and they’re dealt with completely differently, so it keeps the tension high as you wonder what exactly jonathan needs to worry about, and how he should be preparing to deal with it
Our boy Mr. Harker eating his Paprika Hendl is great and all but it‘s infuriating me that Stoker missed the opportunity for a Goulash pun (given that the dishes are pretty similar)

Another now-comedic aspect of 
Dracula
 is the way he carries on this little charade about employing servants--disguising himself to drive Jonathan there and saying “his people” aren’t available to bring in Jonathan’s luggage.
“YES EVERYTHING IS NORMAL HERE I HAVE THE NORMAL NUMBER OF EMPLOYEES HAHA”

Everything about my reading of dracula is going to be overthinking / overanalytical so just getting that out of the way
So I already found themes in the next portion, "4 May"
"Just before I was leaving, the old lady came up to my room and said in a very hysterical way:
"'Must you go? Oh! young Herr, must you go?' She was in such an excited state that she seemed to have lost her grip of what German she knew, and mixed it all up with some other language which I did not know at all." 
Inclusion of "hysterical" here, while not at all unusual, is still important. Hysterical being particularly a coding for mental illness in women. Also the fact that she "lost her grip of what German she knew," again, losing grip being a term that refers to losing control of an aspect of one's mind or thinking. And the particular confusion of language, which is a prevalent experience in certain neurodivergences and mental illnesses. AND madness being grounded until the industrial era in the absence of reason, with language being the predominant vehicle for reason. A confusion of language is to indicate the presence of madness. Society was built on reason, language was needed to establish reason. The tower of babel is a relevant biblical myth of how language systems were viewed as crucial to societal functioning. However, in the industrial revolution that importance shifted. Instead of society being founded on reason and the communication that required, society was founded on labor. Communication is still required, but to a lesser extent. In my opinion, this is a transition that is crucial to our existence under capitalism today. It'll be interesting to see which perspective is taken in the book. 
ANYWAYS takeaways:
Look out for coded language! There's a lot of it in here if I recall. Hysterical seeming to be the first one.
Linguistic confusion! Both a sign and a symptom, I know it's common among us schizo-spec folk. But more conceptually, introduces themes of 'madness' as a kind of foil for 'reason,' which is how it was viewed at the time, to an extent.

I have discovered something and I would like to share it with anyone who crosses my blog.
If you’ve never read Bram Stoker’s 
Dracula
, you might not realize that the book is actually written as a collection of diary entries and letter. Even if you have read 
Dracula
, you might not have realized that those journal entries and letters are dated from May to November. 
Enter 
Dracula Daily
.
This website, which I found by accident, will send you the whole novel in chunks, as letters and diary entries on the days they are found in the book. 
Dracula 
is a slow burn novel. It is meant to be dense and take a while to read and put things together. And what better way than to literally go on the same journey as the characters? If you’ve ever wanted to read it but have issues picking up a full book for whatever reason, this feels like a good way to break up the story and go at your own pace--reading one letter every day can feel more manageable and if you can’t wait for the next email, the book is in the public domain and readily available.
Anyway, not really a point to this post, but I found a Cool Thing and maybe someone else will like it too.

BTW to anyone enjoying Dracula Daily, when it’s finished you might want to check out Leslie Klinger’s annotated Dracula, which does a fascinating job of (completely in-universe) explaining which bits Bram Stoker, who edited the diaries and letters of Jonathan and his friends, had to change for publication, and where he sourced some of the stuff in it. 
My favourite note for today’s entry is related to 
The Law List
, which Klinger footnoted as:
“A directory of attorneys, judges, and related legal personnel, privately published. For many years, the series was known as ‘Clarke’s 
Law List
.’ An 1842 edition is titled ‘Cockell, Teesdale, 
The Law List; Bein a list of the Judges and Officers of the different Courts of Justice Counsel with the dates of their call and Inns of Court; special pleaders, conveyancers; and a complete and accurate list of Certificated Attornies, Notaries, &c in England and Wales, with the London Agents to the Country Attornies...
London: V. and R. Stevens and G. S. Norton (1842).’
Dracula’s collection of books is a curious one. It is tempting to view these motley volumes as the product of a decorator’s desire for a library filled with nicely bound tomes. What purpose could be served by these endless lists of names and addresses? Was Dracula planning to build a portfolio of false identities for himself? Was he planning to recruit highly placed proteges (Kim Newman’s 
Anno Dracula
 and its sequels posit an England in which vampirism has become the pedigree of social respectability)? Or were these perhaps a...menu?”

Dracula: 
Has no reflection, goes straight for Johnathan’s jugular at the sight of his blood, is the only other person in the entire castle, describes history as if he was there for it, has locked and bolted every exit door so Johnathan can’t leave
Johnathan Harker: I’m beginning to think something’s up

Impressions on today’s email:
Utterly in love with Dracula saying “my friend Jonathan Harker” in much the same way Dracula Daily fans say “my close friend Jonathan from real estate”.
I love the emphasis Dracula places on not wanting to give himself away as a foreigner the second he opens his mouth. It's a feeling very familiar to me, that of not wanting to travel until you've mastered the language enough to go unnoticed.
The above would probably tie into a queer reading if we think about the fear of discovery, come to think of it.
Jonathan being excited about books and soothed by the nearby presence of a law textbook is incredibly endearing. My friend.

https://vampires.fandom.com/wiki/Plants_Effective_Against_Vampires#:~:text=Roses%3A%20The%20scent%20of%20a,their%20clothing%20to%20prevent%20attacks.

In Ireland, rowan trees were planted near houses to protect them from the spirits of the dead; in Wales they favored graveyards for their tree plantings. body:
Dear diary. 
Today I had a very delicious meal. I will have to ask for the recipe. The meat was cooked to perfection and the sauce was the best I've ever had. The people around town were acting weird though. Trying to give me whole garlic heads while crying. Maybe it's a local tradition? Was it a side dish or something? I will have to ask my buddy Dracula.
The views are fantastic though. Beautiful trees and you can hear the birds singing. 
I always love a good view specially when it's early spring and everything is that gorgeous green color. That's my favorite color. Not Dracula's apparently since he spend the whole night today talking about how much he loved the color red saying it reminds him of his favorite food. Apparently I remind him of that too. He's such a funny fellow
All in all it was a very nice day

But still in none of the rooms is there a mirror. There is not even a toilet glass on my table, and I had to get the little shaving glass from my bag before I could either shave or brush my hair.

body: This is probably, I don’t know, my fourth or fifth time reading Dracula, because I love it so, but I think my favorite thing about Dracula Daily is seeing Tumblr’s reactions, because it’s giving me a fresh look at the story I love so much. And I know we’ve only gotten two entries so far, but it’s true. Like, for example, the paprika situation. I don’t remember really acknowledging how funny that was before. People loudly declaring, if they were Jonathan, whether they would or would not listen to the woman at the inn begging him not to go. This is a fun way to read my favorite novel, for sure, but seeing all your reactions and perspectives on it is by far the best part so far.

body:
I'm starting to feel a little bad for Bram Stoker writing what at the time of its publishing was certainly a fascinating, suspenseful horror novel, only for it to be consumed by me and many other tumblrines these days as world-class comedy via the virtue of hindsight and us being cynical people. 
Anyway, our Victorian himbo has been pampered aplenty by Dracula and repays him by 
crawling up his ass
 complimenting him on his lingual skill. They share some ghost stories, and I wonder if that treasure the Count mentions is going to be A Thing or he's just being the entertainer there. So far, this reads like Belle's stay in the Beast's castle, what with no visible servants around yet all of our himbo's needs being seen to. Does Dracula really think Jonathan's surname is a patronymic, or is he just playing into his xenophobic stereotyping? He's definitely devoted to his Aesthetic(TM), having bought an old, gloomy estate in England that has huge walls and rusty gates and a creepy pond and all. He's so extra. 
He also claims the bleak old place is because he "seek[s] not gaiety", which, aren't we beyond the point where we have to deny our queer dreams? Then again, Jonathan is also still amazingly deep in denial about things being afoot, or he just really enjoys spending his evenings having pleasant, non-exhaustive conversation with an accomodating gentleman, a sentiment I can get behind.

Ok there is something very captivating in reading the internal battle Jonathan is facing between his hind brain’s terror, the part of him willing to accept superstition, and the rationalist part of him who feels this *cannot* be truth.
Like Dracula literally doesn’t show up in the mirror, grabs him by the throat, and is only warded off with a crucifx. Jonathan realizes he has no way of escaping this castle, and that he is, perhaps, the only living person here. He has all rights to be terrified. And yet, and yet, his secondary reaction is to brush all his fears away as childish. After the mirror is destroyed, he is more annoyed for the sake of his shave. 
Jonathan recognizes and thanks now the woman who gave him the crucifix, but even still, he was taught it was disfavourable and of idoltry. He wonders if the actual item has power or if its comforting bc it meant someone cared enough for him to give it to him for protection.  
His instincts are now overcoming societal nicety and expectation- but he is still pulled to engage with and is fascinated by Dracula. And that pull toward what is terrifying, this conflict, well that just makes good Horror.

body:
Now that everyone is reading Dracula Daily, let me briefly remind you that Transylvania is not a country, but a region of a larger country named Romania. 
And Dracula is inspired by a historical figure Romanians respect and appreciate very much: Vlad (Dracul) Tepes.
Please be mindful of our culture and history when you are having fun.
Sincerely, a very tired Romanian who had to deal with not so well informed readers for years.

body: Since he's everyone's new fave, I just want clarify that Jonathan Harker is a solicitor, not a real estate agent. He's fully a lawyer, qualified to work in civil cases and I think some criminal cases. I'm not sure if I'm a hundred percent clear on the difference between a solicitor and a barrister in the UK (another type of lawyer that I think can appear in higher courts?), but solicitor definitely isn't comparable to a modern real estate agent. He just happens to be working on the legal nitty-gritty of a land deal as his first case.

Actual hot take:
I think maybe a big part of Dracula Daily's success (and perhaps also the success of all those Netflix reality tv shows like Love Is Blind??) is that media has become so asynchronous. You can never really talk to your friends about any shows because either it's "Oh, I haven't seen that but it's on my list" or "I watched that ages ago, I barely remember it, remind me who [character X] was?" or "STOP TALKING, I'm on Season 2, no spoilers!!" 
And it's kind of upsetting, because we cannot really discuss media anymore the way people were able to when a show was on TV and everyone kind of experienced it together. Synchronous media is an event, it's fun, everybody can participate! Now we're drowning in recommendations of what we "should watch", and the list gets longer and longer, but even when we do get around to a particular show, we almost never properly discuss it with the friend who recommended it and it's just frustrating. 
So yeah. My take is that humans actually kind of really enjoy synchronous media consumption, which has been greatly reduced by streaming, and perhaps Dracula Daily is filling that gap for us right now, you know?

Alright but I wasn't the only one who found it fucking hilarious that: Johnathan saw that the count had no reflection and cut himself in shock (and then double checked the reflection thing?) And then throws it out the window. And Johnathans next thought. Out of EVERYTHING, is "Well how the fuck do I shave now? With my watch?"

jonathan harker: i’m much too upset to talk about how beautiful the mountains were, how the long pines carpeted the wild profiles of the great Carpathians, how the rivers ran like silver filigree through that deep green tapestry, how the light graced the mountain-peaks like the kiss of God upon the broad forehead of the world. much too upset to talk about any of that today.
Alert alert! I got an email from my good friend Jonathan and ... is this a clue a see? is he starting to catch on?

Johnathan: I don't think the Count is human- I think he's dangerous, he nearly killed me and was only stopped by the crucifix- I thank the woman who gave it to me despite my judgments, it may have saved my life.
Johnathan: Also he got rid of my mirror which is really annoying. How am I supposed to shave now?
Johnathan: Also also, I am a prisoner in this castle and there are no means of escape. I'm the only living person here, and may be doomed.
Johnathan: Also also also I saw the Count making my bed which was kinda weird. We chatted about Transylvania some, which was fun!

Jonathan's Csirkepaprikás!
I am pretty sure that the paprika chicken recipe Jonathan mentions is csirke paprikás (and in that case  I totally get his obsession. In my favourite restuarant in Budapest, the waiter replies to my "Jo éstet“ with "Csirke paprikás and diet coke?"), and since it will be a while ere Jonathan can share the recipie with Mina I thought I share one variant, that I like to cook:
Ingredients:
2 cloves of garlic
2 onions (on the big side)
4 chickenlegs / or actually just like 200g chicken breast, which I usually use
2 bell peppers
2 tablespoons  paprikapowder (I am weak and usually use sweet paprika and just a dash of te spicy one)
Oil/ lard for frying
2 tomatoes
Water and  pepper and salt as needed.
about 200g creme fraiche
1 table spoon of flour
How to prepare:
Slice the onions, chicken pieces, peppers and tomatoes into cubes
Heat the oil/lard in a  deep pan.
Add onions into the pan, dust heavily with paprika powder.
When the onions are glazed add te chicken and the rest of the powder, and  fry for a few minutes
Add water, turn down the temperature and let it simmer for 30-40 min. Cover pan with a lid. Take care it doesn't burn and refill water as needed (the chicken onion mix should just be covered in water).
After about 20 min add the peppers and the tomates, stir and let simmer some more.
When the pieces of chicken are tender add the creme fraiche, stir and add as much flour a needed to get a smooth but not runny consistency.
Serve with pasta (traditionally noekdly) or potato
So easy that even undead Counts who were too lazy to learn how to cook can do it!
Jó étvágyat!

Dracula Daily, 3 May (reread)
“I had for dinner, or rather supper, a chicken done up some way with red pepper, which was very good but thirsty. (Mem., get recipe for Mina.) I asked the waiter, and he said it was called "paprika hendl," and that, as it was a national dish, I should be able to get it anywhere along the Carpathians. I found my smattering of German very useful here; indeed, I don't know how I should be able to get on without it.”
first of all Our Good Friend Jonathan getting the recipe for Mina is adorable? second of all so funny to think of paprika as an exotic spice! I love the funny little tourist moments

I read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if it were the centre of some sort of imaginative whirlpool; if so my stay may be very interesting. (Mem., I must ask the Count all about them.)
it’s funny and a little sad how excited he is about the mystery and superstitions of the region, and asking the count about it, and knowing how much he will end up not enjoying directly experiencing those superstitions source

Email has been lost to spam filter

domestic.

Goddamn Dracula Daily has taken over my feed and my life as a whole.

Re: the Henry-Irving-as-model-for-Dracula thing, when Dracula says “by our talking I may learn the English intonation; and I would that you tell me when I make error, even of the smallest, in my speaking”, I will now, always and forever, assume that Dracula is aiming to sound like 
this
 recording of a late-career Irving doing the opening to Richard III (in a very BBC voice). And probably imagine him practicing “O for a muse of fire” over and over again, as in every beginner voice verse class I have ever participated in or observed.
This is like when my high school English teacher had the class read the odyssey one chapter at a time every day. Except this is much more fun! ￼

The thing about Count Dracula’s weird diatribe about Vlad Țepeș being Szekely is that it’s probably just poor research on Bram Stoker’s part. 
But I choose to believe this means that Dracula probably isn’t even the Count’s real name. He just kins the OG Dracula, so he cribbed his name and now tells foreigners his headcanons about the real historical figure because he really feels in his little otherkin heart that the real Dracula had to have been Szekely like him.

body:
i've noticed in the dracula daily tag that a lot of people are assuming that by "solicitor" the book means that jonathan harker is something like a real estate agent, and while i appreciate the jokes, i would like to offer a correction:
this man is a LAWYER.
solicitors can deal in things like property law. when jonathan notes in his journal that mina wouldn't like him calling himself a mere clerk because he passed the examination and is now a solicitor, he's likely talking about the bar exam for lawyers. this man is licensed to advise on laws.
i tell you this because reading about this man refusing to ever question anything weird happening to him while blue fires and wolves circle around is much funnier when you know this man is theoretically practiced in law. he's an educated man but such a dumbass that all you need to do to stop him from leaving a spooky castle is feed him roast chicken. he can list off property laws but shrugs at the fact that his new client count dracula is the weirdest motherfucker around. jonathan my good sir please get a clue.

May 5th of Dracula 
I could hear a lot of words often repeated, queer words, for there were many nationalities in the crowd; so I quietly got my polyglot dictionary from my bag and looked them out. I must say they were not cheering to me, for amongst them were "Ordog"—Satan, "pokol"—hell, "stregoica"—witch, "vrolok" and "vlkoslak"—both of which mean the same thing, one being Slovak and the other Servian for something that is either were-wolf or vampire. (Mem., I must ask the Count about these superstitions)
Yes well done Jonathan, let's casually wonder why these peasants are all talking about Satan and vampires. Let's ask the mysterious cloaked figure who's brought me across half a continent and clearly has an influence over these people. Let's just wander in to mortal peril, mad dogs and English men. But its totally fine, he's a full blown solicitor now.
The old man motioned me in with his right hand with a courtly gesture, saying in excellent English, but with a strange intonation:— "Welcome to my house! Enter freely and of your own will!"
Is this a precursor to 'must be invited in' lore?
I caved and subscribed to dracula daily…

It’s my first assignment at this entry level job and I just can’t tell”

Okay, I have a kind of off-the-wall 
Dracula Daily
 question here. 
"...
our driver, whose wide linen drawers covered the whole front of the box-seat—"gotza" they call them—
..." 
There is a Canadian slang term, "gotchies" (also "gonchies" or "gonch"), which means underwear. I never really wondered about the etymology. I assumed it was simply spontaneous nonsense that somehow caught on. 
But maybe "gotchies" is a corruption of "gotza"? So, does anybody know more about the word, like what language it is and how it's really spelled?

It's worth noting that while Stoker definitely drew upon sources 
purporting to describe vampire folklore in establishing rules for his 
own vampires, some of the vampire "lore" you see in play in Dracula is
 original to him. The mirror thing doesn't seem to have been around 
before Stoker. While there are regional superstitions one can track down
 about needing to cover mirrors in the home of the recently dead to 
prevent their corpse from turning vampiric, the idea that vampires cast 
no reflection appears to really have had its start with this novel. 
What's more, it was only part of what was planned in Stoker's notes on 
vampiric irreproducibility. While it never made it into the final text, 
Stoker wrote down vampires also wouldn't show up in photographs (which 
is might be related to Jonathan conveniently mentioning his kodak 
camera) and that even attempting to paint a vampire would fail. 
Apparently painting a vampire was just supposed to end up looking like 
somebody else. Photographs would either come out black or show a 
skeleton or corpse.

body:
Jonathan Harker:
 *narrowly escapes death, saved at the last minute by a crucifix he almost didn't accept: the single casualty of this encounter is an ugly hand mirror*
Jonathan Harker:
 oh no, how am I going to shave :( what if someone sees me with stubble in this creepy deserted castle I'll be so embarrassed, ugh this is so annoying :(

I do think Dracula is extremely charismatic initially, and also very calculating about that charisma.
 There is an instinctive relief at entering shelter especially after such a close encounter with wild beasts in the woods. Jonathan even mentions rejoicing at the sight of a warm hearth and a hot meal.
This very kind greeting: "Welcome to my house. Come freely. Go safely; and leave something of the happiness you bring!"
Asking Jonathan about his journey (which, by the very existence of these epistolaries, we can infer our protagonist greatly enjoys discussing.)
Dracula "choosing" to take care of Jonathan himself instead of having staff do it. Also just generally the disregard for the great difference in their social standings, and treating Jonathan as an equal and a treasured guest.
Yes the townspeople fear him, that is evident. Yes there are also odd things about Dracula's manners and appearances. But I can see why Jonathan was not initially afraid or even particularly hesitant with the villain of the story. And I can imagine  first time readers (prior to the cultural saturation of vampires) initially believing Dracula to be a decent man.

body:
Today, on May 6, 2022, I learned what Dracula Daily is, and I completely love it. I was not expecting to become hooked on the premise of the writing being released the same days as in the books. 
I have never read Dracula or heard of Dracula Daily. Luckily for me, there was only a few entries that I needed to read to catch up on.
I found myself surprised that I actually enjoyed reading Dracula since it was published in the 1800s. The writing is very descriptive, whether it is people or the landscape, which I personally don't really like in writing in general, however, it was necessary to set the scene and atmosphere of what I have read so far.
My thoughts/summary so far:
So Jonathan Harker is a real estate agent and that's why he's going to Count Dracula. (I actually gasped out loud when I read 'You're friend, DRACULA')
Jonathan is the classic oblivious horror main character. Like, why did he not question once of why people don't want him to go. The crowd was literally saying, devil, Satan, etc., and the lady gave you a rosary, tears in her eyes, and told you about the holiday it was. How much more warning do you need?
The way the carriage ride was written actually made me a bit nervous and I genuinely thought that a wolf was going to attack, or that the written equivalent of a jump scare was going to happen. (I don't watch or read a lot of horror stuff, so I get scared easily).
When Jonathan and Count Dracula meet, I was expecting him to be more intimidating??? rude??? scary??? And I was surprised that he is actually nice. He got him a whole roasted chicken just for him and helped with his luggage personally, even though he probably could have asked one of his employees to do it. (also how convenient, it is that Dracula will be away until the afternoon /s)
Some after thoughts:
What was up with the glowing thing in the woods? Will that get explained? I don't know. I'll have to wait until the next time it updates. 
The way this is formatted and now being invested in the story, actually make me look forward to the next update.
I can just go get a copy of Dracula and read it, but something about having a lot of other people also read along side you and also discussing at the same pace as you, seeing drawings aaaaaaaaaand I just realized I am now in the Dracula fandom.

body:
I'm so glad everyone's enjoying 
Dracula
 so this seems like the perfect time to bring up 
Carmilla
Carmilla
 is an 1872 novel by Sheridan Le Fanu and predates 
Dracula
 by 26 years. It inspired Bram Stocker to write 
Dracula
! It's genuinely very well written and engaging (more so than 
Dracula
, at least to me), and one of my favorite books. 
But that's not the best part-the best bit is, that 
Carmilla
 is very very sapphic. It follows Laura, a teenager as she meets and falls in love with Carmilla, the vampire. Of course, other plot happens and the book has some really good quotes;
" 'I have been in love with no one, and never shall,' she whispered, 'unless it should be with you.' 
How beautiful she looked in the moonlight! "
" You will think me cruel, very selfish, but love is always selfish; the more ardent the more selfish. How jealous I am you cannot know. You must come with me, loving me, to death; or else hate me, and still come with me, and hating me through death and after. There is no such word as indifference in my apathetic nature. "
And 
Carmilla
 is what invented the whole lesbian vampire trope! Only, rather than portraying lesbianism as morally wrong or other, Sheridan Le Fanu leaves the lesbianism as just a bit of plot and  fully morally neutral

body:
Hey, to everyone out there who’s enjoying Dracula Daily, I would like to heartily recommend 
The Historian 
by Elizabeth Kostova, the best vampire novel since the original (possibly better than the original!).
It is a novel of Dracula - a truly menacing, horrifying Dracula. In an echo of the way 
Dracula
 is told via documents - letters, diaries, etc - 
The Historian
 also relies heavily on them, from letters to journals to family stories to centuries-old historical documents. It’s told in a nested style through three narrators, all of whom are historians - a young woman in the 1970s, her father in the 1950s, and his thesis advisor in the 1930s - with the letters/diaries/stories of the earlier narrators being experienced by the later ones. In this way, it’s told across three different eras of Europe and gets into all the real historical complexities and context of those periods, such as the Cold-War-era difficulties and dangers of carrying out travel and investigations in eastern Europe. It also draws in vampire mythos from a wider range of places than the original, including a truly fascinating stint in Istanbul.
It moves continually back and forth throughout the three narrators and time periods in a really delightful way, and all of the characters are powerfully engaging. On top of this, it can be a genuinely frightening and chilling read at some points - it’s captured the art of eerie, building horror without gore or cheap scares.
If you like history, or Dracula, and especially if you like both, you are going to 
love
 this book.

body: Am I going crazy or do the events described in Jonathan’s journal not match up with the dates? Jonathan writes a journal entry on the fourth in the afternoon and then gets on the coach. He then get’s picked up by the count and notes when it becomes midnight. So they arrive at the count’s estate on the fifth in the very early morning. He eats a very late supper in the early morning and then writes a journal entry early in the morning on the fifth about his travel and then goes to sleep. He wakes up the next day very late and has “breakfast” and then chats with the count until late into the evening, becoming the sixth. Jonathan then goes to to his room and starts writing about his evening with dracula. This should be very early in the morning on the sixth. But it is dated the seventh? I feel like I’ve missed something. Is Jonathan so sleep deprived he’s messing up the dates? Did he sleep for 24 hours after arriving at the count’s estate? I’m very confused.

tags: You cannot comprehend how many words I can and will write about this character
body:
To develop as a Victorianist, I had to rein in my unrelenting fixation on the fin de siecle’s finest not-quite-actually-mad scientist over the course of my studies. I had to diversify the texts I read. I had to familiarize myself with theory. I had to hone my skills as an instructor. 
Please understand that if this fervor for my boy Bram’s magnum opus continues until the 25th, I am in danger. We are all in danger. The moment the words “Ebb tide in appetite” hit my inbox, I will have to make some decisions as to how many of my years of accumulated speculations regarding 
Dracula’s
 most prominent narrator people really need to hear.

body:
Today’s chapters were a trip. Sad little meow meow is finally having some doubts about Castle Dracula and his really weird host. Aren’t you an observant one! 
Why is the Count standing in the only possible spot where someone could figure out he doesn’t appear in mirrors? Seriously. He could have just waited and tossed the mirror out the window (hilarious move, by the way) when Jonathan wasn’t around. 
*I’m a prisoner!* 😮
*Maybe I shouldn’t say anything to the Count about the fact that he has imprisoned me. I mean, it could be all in my head and how awkward would that be?* (I thought that after the paprika incident he couldn’t get any more British, but I was wrong)
*The COUNT has no servants?!* 😱😱😱 
*Wait. So was HE the driver who can control wolves?! I thought it was a random servant but this is somehow WORSE! The *identity* of the wolf whisperer is the problem!*
*Oh well, let’s talk about history to pass the time! Sorry I couldn’t write down the ENTIRE diatribe, but here’s a very long excerpt in ridiculous detail. I’m sure someone will try to base a whole movie on this one paragraph in the future.*

body: love how jonathan’s reaction to dracula throwing his mirror out of the window was mostly just like “dude what the fuck how am i supposed to shave now :/“

Again you all are missing the point, and missing out on the true comedy of this novel which is: for as strangely cheerful as Jonathan is he IS genre savvy and he DOES think something horrible might happen to him. The last two entries ended with him hoping desperately he'll get to see his family again. Not the words of someone unaware of the danger he's in. The comedy of Dracula is how he looks at the warning signs, SEES them, and his reaction is just to be like ":/. I guess this what I signed up for when I became a real estate agent. Should I have seen this coming?" Like this man is willing to risk joining the legions of the undead if that's where his line of work takes him. Furthermore his naturally buoyant spirit heightens the comedy bc his mind is like "Am I about to die? Man I love my fiance she's the best! Am I about to die? These mountains are gorgeous! Am I about to die? These locals are so kindhearted! Am I about to die? This chicken is really good! Am I about to die? My boss likes me!!! Am I about to die?

this is amazing. Ive never had anything like dracula daily in my life! Ive never watched or read anything on release, neither alone nor with friends, Im perpetually out of the loop so Ive only ever binged things years after they came out. Sure, Dracula is not a new thing in the slightest, however me and probably most of us have never read it and only know the bare bones of what happened.
To get on this website every day, and see the chatter about the new dracula daily chapter, a conversation which everyone who is subscribed to it can enter equally? Its so nice. Its like hanging out with friends and bantering over the newest episode of a tv show. Collectively shaking our heads at our mutual friend Jonathan. I want to have this event repeat for different books, I propose Moby Dick as our next contestant

body:
i am seeing some comments in reblogs that lead me to believe that not all of my followers are aware that dracula daily is free, and 
you can catch up and subscribe here
here are some answers from the faq:
Q
. When does it start?
A
. The first entry is on May 3. That’s when you’ll get the first email!
Q
. When does it end?
A
. The last entry is November 7.
Q
. You’re going to email the whole book?
A
. Yes, in small bits at a time! Some days there’s a lot of activity, some days just a few sentences, and many days nothing at all. You’ll only get an email when there’s action taking place in the book.
Q.
 It’s free?
A.
 It’s free.
Q
. What if I join after May 3?
A
. That’s OK! You’ll still get the daily posts as they happen, and you can check out the archive to catch up. Or grab a copy from your library or local book store to catch up!

Podcast recommendation 
So the Dracula daily tumblr book club phenomenon brought this to my mind.
Do you like horror? Do you like the meme-ish book club feel of the internets reaction to Dracula daily? You might enjoy 
witchhouse media / hppodcraft / strange studies of strange stories. 
The show is rebranding currently so look out for that last name starting in a month or two, there's like 12 years worth of free monthly episodes, the first hundred and fifty free episodes or so focus on the work of HP Lovecraft, they do a good job of calling him out on his racist shit while also talking serious critiques and reviews of the stories as horror and weird fiction. Once the lovecraft era ends, these guys cover a ton of other pulp, horror, scifi, and weird stories and authors, including Robert Chambers, Ray Bradbury, Bram Stoker, Mary Shelly, and more! Patton Oswalt has guest co hosted a few episodes, so that's fun. 
There's like 600 episodes out for patreon members, the two lowest tiers are like 3 and 6 bucks respectively and you get you access to every episode. 
I was in no way paid to say this, don't even know the guys except as a listener.
Anyway, if you like horror and all things weird, you should check it out.

 Hellsing-verse theories. Like how Stoker's descriptions of Dracula make it pretty clear that the Count is old, odd-looking, and kind of off-putting.

body:
Today’s chapter of 
Dracula 
where Dracula primarily talks to Jonathan about England and his own English speaking skills is really great because Dracula is just...really genuinely interesting to listen to? Despite apologizing for his English his particular way of speaking is not only fascinating in its diction and word choice but he’s sort of a wry, funny, emotional man: he’s exactly as charismatic and charming as you would expect Dracula to be but rather than just having Jonathan write in his little notebook how charismatic and charming he is, you actually understand and experience it firsthand just by how enjoyable it is to read his dialogue. Honestly I envy Jonathan Harker for getting to stay up all night drinking and smoking with Dracula talking about English customs and old decrepit houses and legends of blue fire treasures and so on. Don’t you?

Ok im reading dracula daily from the top
I wonder how quick i can find themes of neurodivergence and mental illness this time. Probably a lot sooner now that I know mental illness was thought to emanate as a contagious kind of haze from asylums back around the 1700s.
(For reference: following quote is from Michel Foucault - Madness and Civilization, chapter 7 - The Great Fear)
“Suddenly, in a few years in the middle of the eighteenth century, a fear arose-a fear formulated in medical terms but animated, basically, by a moral myth. People were in dread of a mysterious disease that spread, it was said, from the houses of confinement and would soon threaten the cities. They spoke of prison fevers; they evoked the wagons of criminals, men in chains who passed through the cities, leaving disease in their wake; scurvy was thought to cause contagions; it was said that the air, tainted by disease, would corrupt the residential quarters. And the great image of medieval horror reappeared, giving birth, in the metaphors of dread, to a second panic. The house of confinement was no longer only the lazar house at the city's edge; it was leprosy itself confronting the town..."

Dracula Daily- May 3rd Catch Up
I never post anything to this hellsite, but I guess it's a decent place to put notes about my Dracula Daily experience. I really like the concept- it's an interesting way to interact with the classic, and I don't think I've ever actually read the book!
So yeah- getting here late. Trying to catch up where I can. These are gonna be mostly for my own enjoyment- not really trying to start a dialogue or anything. It just seems... like if I'm putting in the time to read this regularly... I should be... writing something about it...??? if that make sense??? 
SO MAY 3rd
Jonny Harker has discovered the unpredictability of trains (which i absolutely relate to. trains are not on time. sometimes they come not at all. Jonny would def be the person on the platform angrily tweeting at the transit authority) and the magic of paprika (delicious. i concur. kind of want to make paprika hendl sometime now... there was no good description of it, but paprika and chicken sound good. [ok, looked up a recipe. this sounds good. https://noseychef.com/2019/11/01/paprikas-csirke/ ] ) He is doing a lot of people watching and being kinda judgy about it. But the people and places are pretty, and he's excited to be doing this travelogue thing. Also, he got a note from DRACULA which is super jarring because I know what DRACULA is, but Jonny doesn't so I guess they're friends. 
This is kinda fun. Think I'll do this whenever I want. So yeah. RaMbLeS
Finally started reading my Dracula Daily emails and, yeah, okay, I can see why people are on about the paprika lol.

body: As someone who read Dracula a while ago, it's very fun seeing people discover it through Dracula Daily <3 I hope you all have fun!

Me x Reader
“Hi, hello, come visit me, k?
Your friend,
Cat.”
I pick you up at the station, dressed as a chauffeur, you can clearly see it’s me, I’m short and I have pink hair.
As we drive to my home. I get out of the car every two minutes each time I see a dog. You think I growl at them.
We arrive, I go to open the garage and leave you there outside waiting for me. In about 15 minutes after you knocking and ringing the bell multiple times, I open the door dressed as a maid.
“Hi... Cat is waiting for you... Go pee...” I say.
You go to use the bathroom, then you hear me calling you from the kitchen. You walk in to see me out of breath, I’m wearing an expensive silk gown.
“I let my servants retire for the day, help yourself,” I say as I put a whole roasted chicken before you. “I won’t eat, it’s my beauty sleep time. You must be tired. Sleep well, I have a lot of stuff to do tomorrow downtown, see you in 18 hours,” I say and leave.
You are smitten. I have elf ears and very red lips.

body:
For all those newly obsessed by Johnathan Harker’s Worst Business Trip Ever, I have to tell you about my favorite piece of published Dracula fanfic, 
The Dracula Tape by Fred Saberhagen.  
The premise is that Dracula accosts some folks in the 1970s in order to give His side of the story and it’s recorded on a tape deck.  
It’s hilarious though, because it’s basically like “Look, Johnathan Harker had No Idea what was going on.  He didn’t even speak the language, but somehow he claims to know what people were saying to him?  Cause he knows a few German words?”  And like “look I was just an innocent vampire trying to buy some property and he jumped to All Kinds of conclusions, really.” 
And like it makes...a lot of good points about the novel, actually.  (Like it wasn’t ME that killed Lucy, maybe it was those experimental blood transfusions that didn’t pay any attention to BLOOD TYPE, VAN HELSING.)
So yeah, highly recommend it after you’ve read the original.

Some word choices were interesting to me: 
- “kodak” uncapitalized:
“I could not enter it, as I had not the key of the door leading to it from the house, but I have taken with my kodak views of it from various points.”
- “remissness” is an extremely awkward word:
“With an apology for my remissness, I went into my own room to get the papers from my bag.”
- “boyar” and “Bradshaw’s Guide” I didn’t know & looked up

body:
“We should have Frankenstein Daily next!”
No. You think you want this? I mean the dramatic irony of knowing who Dracula is kind makes the reading hilarious, but reading emails from Walton while he fusses over Frankenstein in the North Pole AFTER I know what he did? Just pure rage. “Oh I’m afraid I might not hear the end of this brilliant man’s tale, poor Victor’s health is declining!” Good. I hope he doesn’t get better. I hope he fuckin dies. Why are you writing this to me?

Jonathan seems well. Must talk to him later about his tendency to describe people he meets in extreme detail, I don't think they'd appreciate it especially when they were so wonderfully nice to him.
I hope the Count can explain the local beliefs about 'were-wolves and vampires' but he doesn't seem the superstitious type. Not one mention of him crossing himself. Might not even be catholic.

See, it's just

 to get into the dracula daily fad because like, ok, if it was a tv show more people would have reservations about joining it because who knows if it lives up to the hype, or if you have time to sit down and watch it, etc., etc., but this is about a public domain victorian novel everyone knows and no one is here for stanning characters or guessing where the plot will go or whatever, everyone is just making memes with the material they're given with each mail. It's the fandom experience sans 50% of the risk.

Okay i. . . like. . . i DO agree that it’s very cool that people are reading Dracula for the first time and it’s nice of people to preserve the experience for them when possible. If you encounter spoilers I understand that that’s disappointing but it really truly does not mean anyone WRONGED you by not tagging spoilers for a 125 year old book.

I do agree with the general sentiment of "Jonathan Harker is an idiot." But can we also acknowledge the role of Western condescension in his decision making?
He describes leaving Vienna as passing from the West into the East. In effect saying he is leaving the place where he deems people like him to be rational and entering a place where he dismisses their concerns as superstition.
Regularly thinking of the locals as irrational barbarians blinds him to the fact that he's walking into a vampire's castle.

"Take care," he said, "take care how you cut yourself. It is more dangerous than you think in this country." Then seizing the shaving glass, he went on: "And this is the wretched thing that has done the mischief. It is a foul bauble of man's vanity. Away with it!" and opening the heavy window with one wrench of his terrible hand, he flung out the glass, which was shattered into a thousand pieces on the stones of the courtyard far below. Then he withdrew without a word. It is very annoying, for I do not see how I am to shave, unless in my watch-case or the bottom of the shaving-pot, which is fortunately of metal.

body: My favorite thing about Dracula Daily is the reaction journey you go on trying to be generous to our friend Jonathan in which your FIRST reaction is like "this fucking IDIOT" and then you're like "well hang on, hold on, let's be fair, like, it's hard to be genre savvy when you are IN THE BOOK wherein the genre is basically invented; like of course he doesn't know that Dracula is Dracula, I am approaching this from the standpoint of someone living in modern times, I need to try and imagine a world in which Dracula is just another name" and then you come IMMEDIATELY back around to being like "oh yeah no even grading on a curve and including genre-savviness handicaps this guy is the stupidest man alive nvm"

the thing that i think dracula daily has going for it that puts it so far above everything else right now is the fact that it’s totally free and completely unexpected, because you have these mega-billion dollar entertainment corporations competing for our time and there’s more tv/movie/etc content choices out there than ever before (that they all want you to pay for) but it just. gets boring after a while. 
but dracula daily just came so out of left field that i was like “of COURSE i want to hear about your business trip to a 
totally normal
 castle to meet a 
totally normal 
guy named dracula mr. harker” and now i’m so literally invested in the story of this novel that like. i could have written my required big senior year english paper on in high school and that i could easily just get from the library tomorrow and read more than just a few hundred words a day

body:
I have succumbed.
(To be fair, I haven’t read the novel since I was a teenager, and I’m pretty sure that was in translation, so...)
Also, I am slightly annoyed that Fred Saberhagen’s got another 55 years or so to being public domain, because his “The Dracula Tape” is a delightful counterpoint, with a Dracula having many problems with his nice friend Jonathan Harker - including that he’s suffering from the “damnable English propensity for minding one’s own business, which in my opinion Harker carried to lengths of great absurdity, even for a discreet and tactful young solicitor. There he sat, upon the exposed seat of my caleche, watching my antics with the cairns but saying nothing,” while Dracula as the coachman is trying to invite the start of a conversation going: “So, vampires are real.”
is this what it feels like to be in a book club??
thinking about him (my good friend jonathan) :(
I do love that Dracula *noticeably* pretends not to understand sometimes to avoid questions.

protip for any gmail user who signed up for dracula daily and hasn't been getting the first couple emails, check your "promotions" tab - that's where they were going for me.
you can drag one from there to "primary" and that should fix it going forward

tags: this being a time when being Catholic in British ruled Ireland was a long held trouble
body: Also I do find it super interesting the Catholic vs Protestant bent in this book. Bram Stoker is Irish, and supported Home Rule, but was raised Protestant. Jonathan is Protestant and has immediate rebuke of Catholic ‘superstition’ but realizes ‘oh this is rebuking evil’. Van Helsing, who we meet later on, is the hero who can take on the evil- but he is a Catholic.

One time on vacation i stayed at an Airbnb in Niagara and the guy had mirrors on the fence outside of his front door.  It worked great as a last glance. Loved it. Anyways Johnathan Harker is a worker on his first big business trip he's not going to comment on the mirror status because he's not a prick. He's polite. Clearly.

Really, I am so confused. Was Jonathan riding the coach for more than 24 hours? Or did he sleep more than 24 hours? What is with the timeline? There seems to be a day missing. 
He gets into the coach on May 4. He rides for a while first with this coach, then with Dracula with a fake beard, until he arrives at Dracula after midnight, which makes it May 5. Jonathan eats, writes about his adventure under the date of May 5 and goes to sleep.
It could be that because it was just after midnight Jonathan has written the date of a previous day and actually all the driving took more than a day?
Because if not, then he was sleep ing awefully long?
So, after arriving on May 5 he sleeps until about 5 p.m. (of the same day? May 5?), eats his breakfast/dinner and talks with Dracula for a whole night until morning (May 6?), and before going to sleep in the morning he wrots his diary entry under May 7. When has it become May 7?
Have I missed something? What is happening with the time?
Jonathan Harker deserves nothing but praise and affection

body:
Even if you've already read Dracula before, getting each entry as an email-a-day lends itself SO WELL to the epistolary form, it's a whole new experience. It's a blast to pretend you're getting a friendly email from your Good Buddy Jonathan Harker. Every evening I sit down and read the days entry and draft out a little return email in my head. RE: 
May 5. The Castle
. Dear Jonathan, congrats on passing your bar exam! Don't forget to send me those recipes, and for the love of God hold onto that rosary - I've been fine btw, I'll send you some pictures of my new cat. I'm. I'm sorry, how many wolves. Wait, your client's teeth are  w h a t

body: I wasn't going to make fun of Jonathan before but now that he asked Dracula, "Hey, what was up with the blue fires my driver was chasing?" and Dracula was like, "The blue fires are markers on your mini-map where lootboxes can be found!" and Jonathan was like, "Of course." I think it's time to start bullying him.

I hope everyone is not only ready to experience the majestic weirdness that is 
Dracula
 but also to gradually learn about how the novel has never been adapted with anything approaching 100% accuracy and how every 
Dracula
 film is an even weirder remix of the original. All your blorbos have been bizarrely cut and spliced with other blorbos throughout this book’s cinematic history. 
We have already passed the point in the novel where--in one of its most iconic film re-imaginings--the viewer has been introduced to Count Dracula’s pet armadillos and a single vampire bee crawling into its own little bee coffin.

body: I sit at the window in my dorm looking longingly for my e-letter from the Dracula man

Dracula Daily, 4 May (reread)
“Jonathan feels ridiculous but also uncomfortable” HGFDHJ
Another email from Our Good Friend Jonathan! 
When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. 
Having A Normal One!
"It is the eve of St. George's Day. Do you not know that to-night, when the clock strikes midnight, all the evil things in the world will have full sway?“
I must have slept through that
 She then rose and dried her eyes, and taking a crucifix from her neck offered it to me. I did not know what to do, for, as an English Churchman, I have been taught to regard such things as in some measure idolatrous, and yet it seemed so ungracious to refuse an old lady meaning so well and in such a state of mind.

the crew of light, 2022 edition
jonathan: still a solicitor, aspiring recipe blogger
mina: still a teacher. still has a special interest in trains. 
seward: still a doctor for mental health inpatients. somehow hasn’t been struck off by the gmc for the renfield stuff
van helsing: also somehow still a doctor and part-time vampire hunter
lucy westenra: influencer, but is somehow really nice about it
holmwood: just graduated uni with a degree in business so he can take over his dad’s company or something.

Daily Drac!
our friend is back to writing to us, and with a lengthy tale of what he’s been up to! lots of reading, and some fine food, too. seems like the Count has less of a fondness for paprika than those in the town, thank god for poor Jonathan’s digestive tract. it’s funny, we haven’t seen any servants yet. Dracula Daily
I’m going to read along with the daily Dracula email thing where you sign up 
here
 and get Bram Stoker’s epistolary novel in ‘real time’, ie on the dates that the letters are written or the news articles published. Then I will get what the rest of you are posting about!
Join me? Or mute the tag ‘dracula daily’ if you prefer and still want to follow me because I’ll be posting thoughts :)
So far I’m enjoying Fusspot Traveler and foodie, solicitor Jonathan Harker, it is so relatable that he doesn’t want to go far from the train station for fear of missing the train. And some of the passages are really evocative - “

There was everywhere a bewildering mass of fruit blossom—apple, plum, pear, cherry; and as we drove by I could see the green grass under the trees spangled with the fallen petals. In and out amongst these green hills of what they call here the "Mittel Land" ran the road, losing itself as it swept round the grassy curve, or was shut out by the straggling ends of pine woods, which here and there ran down the hillsides like tongues of flame. 

“
That’s really what it’s like here in central Europe right now! 
Dracula’s driver is doing weird stuff with will-o-the-wisps, I wonder if that ever gets explained? (Also the driver is actually the Count in disguise, isn’t he, that’s not subtle. Which implies that he’s pretending to be a bunch of his own servants and omg that is so funny).
“Enter freely and of your own will!“ is such a good way to be technically polite but also really worrying when welcoming guests.

I have long white teeth (that’s how I got my name) and a long white moustache with white streaks that reaches my mid back and red eyes like limpid blood and a lot of people tell me I look like my predecessor Dracula (if you don’t know who he is get da hell out of here!!) I’m not related to Attila but I wish I was cause he’s a major fucking hottie. I’m a vampire and my teeth are long and white. I have pale white skin. I’m also a Count, and I live in a creepy castle in Transylvania where I’ve been for quite some time (I’m an age.) I’m a Goth (in case you couldn’t tell) and the blood of every conqueror ever flows through my veins. I’m also a goth (in case you couldn’t tell) and I wear mostly black. For example today I was wearing a black shirt, black trousers, a black cape, and black mid-thigh boots. I was wearing no makeup. I was walking around inside my castle. Dracula: May 3

So fun fact, I believe in Iceland (?) the Dracula story that they know is *COMPLETELY DIFFERENT* from the Dracula we know. That's because the guy in charge of translating Dracula to Icelandic was a mega fan boy of Bram Stoker's Dracula that wanted to get his own fanfiction published so when it came to translating Dracula... He... Just... Did... And it wasn't revealed to be fanfiction until after his death if I'm not mistaken. And apparently, this Icelandic version is often regarded as *better* than the original.

body:
My favourite part of today's (May 8) update is when Jon is surprised by how much comfort the crucifix brings him, since he's always been told that to deruve comfort from it is idolatrous. This is what he says -
It is odd that a thing which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my mind about it. 
It's so moving - when we invest things with meaning and they actually seem to work, is it that the meaning that comes true or the very fact that we invested in them? For Jon, the crucifix carries meaning despite his beliefs because of the very fact that he was once (not too long ago) amongst people who were looking out for him, protecting him even. 
And don't even get me started on the last line. Beneath all the fear (Jon really is scared out of his mind now!) he still wants to figure out these things, to unentangle his thoughts. And he says "some time, if it may be" - the future (and being alive in the future) holds the possibility of all this thought! He wants to live not only to return home and to get back to his life but also to figure out all this philosophical stuff.

body:
Paprika Hendl
Ingredients:


1 lb (454 g) chicken, cut into serving sized pieces


2 tbsp olive oil or butter

2 chopped onions



1 chopped green chile  




1/2 tsp sugar (optional) 




2-4 cloves of garlic (optional) 





2 tbsp paprika 





1 tsp chili powder for color (optional) 





1/2 cup (118 ml) tomato puree  


1 tbsp powdered black pepper 



salt to taste 





5 to 6 chopped coriander mint leaves (for garnish)






1/2 cup (118 ml) sour cream






2 tbsp flour





1/2 cup of small chunks of bacon (optional)




1.
Sauté green chili, onions (and sugar), until the onions caramelize and turn reddish brown.  
2.  Add chopped garlic and sauté

 until it turns brown.
3.  Add the chicken, 1tbs of the paprika, (the chili powder) and salt.  Mix and fry 5 minutes.
4.  Add tomato puree and cover.  Simmer 45 minutes.
5.  Mix remaining 1 tbs of paprika with the flour and sour cream until well mixed - blender or by hand - to make sauce.
6.  Pour sauce over chicken, sprinkle with pepper and coriander, then cover and simmer 10 minutes more.
7.  Serve with pasta ( mushroom tortellini?) and optional bacon.

Dracula thoughts
I'm so glad Dracula Daily is back! This was a joy last year but I failed to keep up. Trying again! And already reading three days at once.
May 3rd
 
I love that it's just a travel blog. So many nice recipes. A bit of history. Complaining about the locals in deeply orientalising and racist terms. Just typical British things.
And then the letter from the Count, seeing you to-morrow. Subtly making everything clear its his domain.
May 4th
Then we have everyone desperately scared of the Count and Jonathan just dismissing it as a bunch of strange crucifix wearing yokels. So British. Idiot. They literally crossed themselves and he's so blasé.
I love some of the active writing "Here comes the coach!" to give you that sense it's all real time.

The best, absolute best part of this whole Dracula Daily experience isn't just that a bunch of people are reading Classical Literature™️. It's that a bunch of people are reading Classical Literature *for fun*. There's no critical analysis or essays to write about sex in Victorian England or whatever your pretentious high school English teacher wanted you to write about. It's just a bunch of nerds approaching the subject matter on their own terms and having fun. All Classical Literature™️ should be approached this way.
I have not actually read Dracula before, nor have I seen any actual adaptations, and only have the broadest, most vague idea of the actual plot, so I seem to be in for a Treat

okay I know we’re having fun dunking on Jonathan for ignoring the red flags and continuing on to Dracula’s castle but listen. now that I’m thinking about it makes absolute sense because like. he’s got to be pretty young right? like if he’s just gotten his real estate license and he’s engaged to be married for (I presume) the first time he’s probably not much older than early 30s at most. that’s the headcanon I’m going with anyway.
so put yourself in his shoes. you’re a young professional recently certified to work in a potentially very lucrative field and your boss sends you abroad to help a client buy and sell property. but wait, this isn’t just an ordinary client, this client is a COUNT. a nobleman. somebody wealthy enough to purchase property in another country. the commission on this sale is going to be very nice, and he might refer his similarly wealthy friends to you if you do a good enough job. this is an opportunity to really make a name for yourself in the field, and on top of that you’ve got a wife to support. 
I’m just saying, if I, a 27 year old millennial, was him and I was facing the prospect of a big payday and a career boost when I’m trying to build a life for myself, the locals are gonna have to give me a more compelling reason to stay away than just bad vibes. I’m just saying, he’s a Victorian millennial.

Friends who are reading Dracula daily! May I suggest the podcast “Murray Mysteries” a modern, queer adaptation of the original novel? 
I will warn you, though, it does not START with Jonathan’s travels (but with Mina and Lucy who are no less fantastic) We get to see Jonathan’s road trip at the start of season 2. Jonathan in it is absolutely delightful and every single one of your memes will still be applicable if you get this delightful voice in your head as my boy, Jonny, the asexual wonder
