What I really like is that. Like I have not really been able to get through Dracula for a variety of reasons but one of the big ones was that it always felt like it dragged, as I struggle with turn of the century narrative styles and reading emotion into it. 
So having t broken up and happen in real time like this is really helping my ability to understand the story beats, and having immediate, joking reactions from other people help me understand things like Jonathan’s paprika allergy which I never picked up on. It’s making it far more enjoyable than any of my experiences with reading the book before, and I’m excited about the idea of reading more

Holy fuck I’m reading Dracula Daily and I never realized that the Quintessential Vampire™ was literally nothing like how pop culture had made him out to be??? I never read Dracula because I was always under the impression that he was meloncolic and woeful and just wallowing in his sorrows? Your telling me that he’s just a dramatic little fuck with a hemoglobin deficiency???

So I've perused the first three days of journal entries from this Jonathan Harker. I've yet to learn exactly who the Mina he mentions is, but he's quite invested in her opinions and entertainment. Rather more so than any of the women he meets in his travels - he'll describe their garments and cultural background but gets quite dismissive about the rest of them. Wisdom, or disinterest? Hmm. He gives far more interest to the men he meets, marveling at their garments and hair, mustaches and beards, eyes and teeth. 
He pays quite a bit of attention to Count Dracula and his driver. Who may be the same man, as both have pointy teeth and remarkable strength? And an affinity for wolves, it seems.
Still no word on why the driver was chasing blue flames all night.
Finally learned what Jonathan is there for. More or less. He's a solicitor (lawyer type) and there's some sort of real estate dealings he'll be helping the Count with. Honestly, I took him for a food blogger or travel guide writer...
Chicken, by the way, works wonders on this man's nerves. Far more so than rosaries and crucifixes. But hey, food and a cozy fire can fix a lot of things.
I'm sure he'll be fine, the townsfolk are just superstitious and the castle and Count are just old.

...taking a crucifix from her neck offered it to me. I did not know what to do, for, as an English Churchman, I have been taught to regard such things as in some measure idolatrous, and yet...
I'm sure that smarter and better-read people than me have written on this (my horror expertise is more in film and my literary enjoyment is enthusiastic but less academic) but it strikes me as interesting how early on in the story Stoker establishes the protection against vampires as being no just Christian (despite already establishing the setting as a place where 'every known superstition in the world is gathered') but specifically Catholic. There's so much sort of... Not necessarily doubleness, but questioning of the hard boundaries between things which seem both very similar and irreconcilably different (life/death/undeath, heterosexuality/queerness, Catholicism/Protestantism, Ireland/England/UK/Everywhere Else, etc). Particularly considering Stoker was an Irish Protestant in favour of home rule but retaining membership of the United Kingdom and that's not even touching the homoerotic subtext and the extreme likelihood of Stoker being not straight. Like I just... It does, in a weird way, seem like an unexpectedly confessional novel

Just wait until they get to who in-universe writes/compiles the text itself.

Wondering how much of our embrace of Dracula Daily & Jonathan Harker can be attributed to Bram Stoker's good fortune of naming 
Dracula
's first POV character something that would work equally well in the 1890s and the 2020s.
Like, if you went to a bar tonight and met a young man named Jonathan Harker who was studying law or working at a real estate firm, you wouldn't bat an eyelash at his name or his profession. You'd just be like "Yeah, this is Some Dude."
So then I think that makes it easier for us to be like "Jonathan is my new best friend! I just got an email from my buddy Jonathan on his wild Romanian road trip!"
Basically I'm wondering whether we'd have the same reactions to Dracula Daily if Jonathan Harker was instead named Basil Hallward, or Geoffrey Utterson, or Edward Prendick (to list some other characters from British novels of the time who unwittingly get mixed up in Gothic shenanigans).

There are many odd things to put down, and, lest who reads them may fancy that I dined too well before I left Bistritz, let me put down my dinner exactly.

body:
earlier this week:
*scrolling, notices a random post about Dracula that seems eerily like a very modern take* ...huh. must be a new adaption out. or a fandom for an adaption I haven’t seen. k
(later, as posts go from a very few to semi-common)
...alright, new fandom? new, bigger fandom. for an adaption that sounds weirdly like the original book. somebody’s doing it right. k have fun y’all
(post about Dracula Daily email appears)
I’m... 
what?
 well okay. at least somebody’s appreciating the classics. no idea how the hell somebody came up with the email thing, and also 
why
. but whatever. weird fandom explosion tho, thought we were done with the vampire thing
(a day or two later, as posts start to occur somewhat frequently)
for a book that’s *checks date* a hundred and twenty-five years old y’all have 
really 
hopped on the blorbo train with this Jonathan Harker dude huh? can’t believe I’m probably gonna start seeing gay vampire fanfic of characters that are a hundred and twenty-five years old on my dash soon. gay vampire fic, sure. gay vampire fic from 
1897...
*glances at Sherlock Holmes fandom* ...actually y’know what nevermind, this is normal
(several of the blogs I follow are now thoroughly invested. there are memes. there are passages being quoted. somehow I have yet to see gay vampire fic)
...okay, fandom, I’ve literally no idea how the hell I’m not seeing a new ship cropping up like mad. also 
why are you posting memes of a hundred and twenty-five-year-old book
. what is this about Dracula Red Flags. wtf is the running joke about the shaving mirror. WHY ARE WE TALKING ABOUT DRACULA BEING A WEIRD HOST 
WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE ON ABOUT
also I knew the original Dracula was 
not 
altogether anything like the modern Twilight-esque vampire but I’m sorry why the hell does this sound like this Jonathan Harker guy just wandered into a random dude’s home and started writing letters home about how weird a host he was without taking Stranger Danger into account. sir why haven’t you left. sir do you have any survival instinct
(continuing to watch the nonsense unfolding)
...why do I feel vaguely invested by proxy
also why are people saying that the daily letters are like actual correspondence from a friend. what, a hundred and twenty-five-year-old dude bestie? your friend that happened to time-travel and lose half his memory and, for whatever reason, has the common sense of your average “horror movie character that dies first” trope? who practically 
inspired 
that trope? who probably writes in a vaguely headache-inducing style because 
old book?
 
and y’all are reading this like the morning newspaper except without the soul-crushing doomsday predictions? or the daily fanfic update from some crazy author who somehow has the organizational skills and legendary all-desired Aladdin’s First Wish ability to actually consistently write enough fic that they 
can 
update daily?
what is going 
on
(it is five days after the mayhem began. there is fanart. there are rant posts. memes abound. Jonathan Harker is apparently now the newest, most popular himbo and blorbo. Dracula Daily has appeared on an official Tumblr “fandoms of the week” post. I am observing one of the fastest fandom blow-ups I’ve seen ever)
...*sighs*
*searches Google for Dracula Daily*
*opens up the webpage and considers for a moment. the mental “let’s not get dragged into this mess” wall is falling apart. teetering on the edge. this close to death. it is screaming 
what are you about to get yourself into
*
*curiosity gremlin is banging pots and pans and screaming and leaping around and kicking the wall and generally being destructive*
well fuck this.
*enters email and hits “subscribe”*

tags: i know it's only cause i'm not in it
body:
aHA I did find the critical history of Dracula i wrote in college in 2014, titled “A Vampire Can Be a Lot of Things” which is basically...an overview of the history of Dracula literary criticism. was curious what might be in there so I went through it and hoo boy now I remember why it was so fun writing a history of lit crit on Dracula and it’s because people will say 
anything 
about it

"Richardson was the first to articulate
the theory that the novel was about an Oedipal struggle between the
‘bad’ father figure of Count Dracula, who hoards the novel’s
women rather than allowing the ‘sons’ of the novel to possess
them. Van Helsing, in this reading, provides an alternate ‘good’
father who is willing to surrender his ownership of the women.
Richardson concludes his psychoanalytic reading of Dracula by
examining Bram Stoker’s biography to unearth a father fixation in
Stoker’s own life.”

“Prior
to the 1970s, the only other major piece of criticism on 
Dracula

was
Richard Wasson’s “The Politics of Dracula,” which addressed the
geographical divide in the novel between the West and the East as
represented by the Balkan region. [...] Rather than being an anxiety about the father figure, the Count
represents the encroaching East that threatens by subversion and
violence that turn the West, as represented by England, against
itself.”
“Christopher
Bentley, writing in 1972 in 
Literature
and Psychology, 
picked
up the discussion of sexuality in 
Dracula,

arguing
that the sexual symbolism of the novel indicated the repressed and
rejected desires of Stoker’s Victorian contemporaries. The vampire
serves as an outlet for sexual expression while keeping the human
characters suitably pure and asexual.”
“Phyllis
Roth, however, argues in “Suddenly Sexual Women in Bram Stoker’s

Dracula
”
that 
Dracula

is
a novel hostile to female sexuality and rooted in the pre-Oedipal and
potentially hostile relationship to the mother. She points out that
the novel reinforces the dichotomy between the sensual woman, who is
bad, and the sexless woman, who is good. Roth claims that the attacks
on Lucy and Mina by Dracula are the repressed desire of human men to
commit violence against their figurative mother.”
“Mark
Hennelly (1977) analyzes 
Dracula

as
a gnostic quest to revitalize the “Victorian wasteland.”
Victorian England requires revitalization from the foreigner Van
Helsing and Dracula, and the incorporation of new methods of thought
into the skeptical, scientific climate of the end of the century.”
“In
1980, Burton Hatlen wrote on the potential of a Marxist
interpretation of romantic literature by focusing on 
Dracula.

His
claim was that the vampires in
 Dracula

represent
the symbolic Other that threatens the bourgeois order of 19
th

century England. The vampire is thus a sexual, cultural, and social
threat to the good professional class represented by Jonathan Harker
and his companions.”

“Meanwhile,
Christopher Craft (1984) discusses the ways in which “sexual
inversion” and the reversal of gender roles in the novel play out
Victorian anxieties about homosexuality and sexual roles. The vampire
mouth is of particular interest to Craft, as it is both an orifice
and a means of penetration.”

“In
1988, Stevenson argues in “A Vampire in the Mirror: The Sexuality
of Dracula” against an Oedipal interpretation of the novel at all,
claiming that rather the threat Dracula poses is that of a foreigner
who threatens to subvert and deracinate good English women, blurring
the divide between the “in” group of England and its outsiders.
Stevenson follows both Wasson and Hatlen in seeing Dracula’s sexual
threat as implicitly racialized, rather than solely psychological.”

“According
to Arata, the fear expressed by the novel is that the energetic and
potent undead will overtake the sexless living of the British Empire.
At the same time, however, Count Dracula’s behavior and methods
both recall British colonial practices turned against the imperial
nation. Arata also notes that Jonathan Harker’s Orientalism in the
first part of the novel is reflected in Dracula’s own
“Occidentalism.””
“Elizabeth
Bronfen in 1999, meanwhile, approaches the novel from another
direction, examining its relationship to death. She employs a reading
of Lacan in her analysis, arguing that 
Dracula

illustrates
two responses to the need to replace a deceased person with a symbol,
like that of a grave: the hysteric and the obsessional.”
it just is legitimately funny to me that if you look at a chronological throughline of Dracula criticism from the nineteenth to the twenty-first century you see academics of pretty much every analytical approach looking at the novel and going “oh I can work with that”

something is very wrong with your friend

which is deeply sad. but also really funny bc we have dracula like ‘yes i totally have servants. excuse me a moment. i need to go...definitely not clear the table bc i have real live human servants to do that’ and then we have jonathan going ‘yes. that sounds good and reasonable. i definitely believe that you have real live human servants and aren’t in the other room clearing everything up yourself. this is fine.”

I've seen quite a few people telling that Frankenstein should be the next book to be emailed to ala Dracula daily, but actually the format doesn't quite work here
But you know what book would be perfect for the email format ? 
Dangerous Liaisons
First because it is also an epistolary novel
Second because I feel like English speakers could benefit from reading some foreign literature
And most importantly, it's a book entirely composed of gossip and scandals, which make it one of the funniest genre to discuss with friends. Believe me, there's nothing quite like being 
shocked
 about what imaginary nobles were doing some 250 years ago, everyone is an horrible little person and it's very entertaining
Anyway, you have my proposition. Dangerous Liaisons. A masterpiece.

We all joke about Jonathan Harker not knowing he's in the book 
Dracula
, but the thing is... it's only him. Everyone else he meets earl on knows full well that he's walking towards his certain doom. They, like us, have the social context needed to know that Dracula is the legendary vampire Dracula.
The most saddest part is that they try to save him. The people he meets offer him protection and advice, even going so far as trying to trick him into turning back when he doesn't listen. But Jonathan Harker will never listen because as an English solicitor, as a well-off white man, he looks down upon everything he sees instead of looking with open eyes.
In short, he's screwed because he can't handle paprika.

body: if there’s one thing bram stoker’s dracula is not, it’s subtle

"I was not sleepy, as the long sleep yesterday had fortified me; but I could not help experiencing that chill which comes over one at the coming of the dawn, which is like, in its way, the turn of the tide. They say that people who are near death die generally at the change to the dawn or at the turn of the tide; any one who has when tired, and tied as it were to his post, experienced this change in the atmosphere can well believe it."
So here's the thing: that is almost exactly how Dracula dies.
Bram Stoker was 
very 
good at foreshadowing.

body: Dracula kinda a gilf

What I think is really interesting within the excerpts of Dracula that we've read so far is the way that Bram Stoker has chosen to write the people of the Transylvanian region. It's very... othering. He clearly has a deep fascination with the diverse mesh of cultures within the region, but its giving very "English anthropologist fascinated with what they believe to be a less 'civilized' culture." I'm curious about how much of his descriptions are based upon authentic research of the region and how much of it is his own fictionalized take.
This is really bringing me back to me AP Lit days. I feel like I want to read analysis papers.
I cannot wait until everyone discovers Lucy Westenra.

It’s the Existential Vibes I’m getting from Dracula for me. Like the way Jonathan describes certain almost unnameable feelings I’ve felt before, like when he’s watching his former passengers who were worried about him disappear in the distance. 
“Without a word he shook his reins, the horses turned, and we swept into the darkness of the Pass. As I looked back I saw the steam from the horses of the coach by the light of the lamps, and projected against it the figures of my late companions crossing themselves. Then the driver cracked his whip and called to his horses, and off they swept on their way to Bukovina. As they sank into the darkness I felt a strange chill, and a lonely feeling came over me…”
Like have you ever watched a car drive away and slowly get further and further away and gotten that Feeling?
Or how he managed to describe that weird feeling you get when you’ve stayed up all night and you start to see the first hints of pale dawn light. 
“but I could not help experiencing that chill which comes over one at the coming of the dawn, which is like, in its way, the turn of the tide. They say that people who are near death die generally at the change to the dawn or at the turn of the tide; any one who has when tired, and tied as it were to his post, experienced this change in the atmosphere can well believe it.”

"I seek not gaiety nor mirth, not the bright voluptuousness of much sunshine and sparkling waters which please the young and gay. I am no longer young; and my heart, through weary years of mourning over the dead, is not attuned to mirth. Moreover, the walls of my castle are broken; the shadows are many, and the wind breathes cold through the broken battlements and casements. I love the shade and the shadow, and would be alone with my thoughts when I may."

They were evidently talking of me, for every now and then they looked at
 me, and some of the people who were sitting on the bench outside the 
door—which they call by a name meaning "word-bearer"—came and listened, 
and then looked at me, most of them pityingly. I could hear a lot of

looked them out. I must say they were not cheering to me, for amongst 
them were "Ordog"—Satan, "pokol"—hell, "stregoica"—witch, "vrolok" and

I suppose I should place a disclaimer at least once before continuing with my inane antics:
I have read Dracula MANY times. I also majored in English and am familiar with reading through different lenses. I am aware of the negative that is within the book, that begins with Jonathan being an absolute jackass about the people that aren’t like where he comes from, the train statement, etc…and more—that I’m not going to mention because century old spoilers!
I know the portrayal of the Romanian people leaves something to be desired, and the history, and please always be sure to do some research before you start feeling a certain way about people. You can never know the biases the author OR characters will/won’t have until you start reading. There are great articles out there that discuss this point, and the other ones I so know Tumblr will gravitate towards.
However, one can be aware of this and still enjoy the book.
Please don’t assume others are going to enjoy everything and please don’t be mad at those who like the book. Don’t be expecting people to focus on the same thing you are focused on and be mad that they’re reading it differently than you. Let people vent their frustrations and their joy. Please don’t be snooty to those who have just barely picked up the book, either.
It’s pretty clear the majority will be reading this text with their personal experiences in mind.
This is my statement on this matter, not that I get anons at any rate to worry about this in the first place. I think it just would be great if we all could enjoy things throughout the whole process.
Having said that, off to go read the next entry!!!

body: Personally, I don’t think it’s a problem that I have cultural knowledge of Dracula and have an idea of where this is heading. Sure I don’t exactly experience the suspense as it goes and everything is lent that edge of dramatic irony, but I choose to regard that as a feature. It’s like those posts (either about Greek plays or about Shakespeare, or maybe it was about Hadestown), about experiencing plays while knowing the stories already. It lends something to it, that you know how it goes, but that you’re telling it anyway, and in a way, experiencing it anew through the (re)telling of it.

I didn’t really have any comments on yesterday’s entry of Dracula, but today (5/8) got me thinking!
First off, kudos to Jonathan for figuring out he’s in danger in like...3 days?  Took him a bit but he got there.  Personally I’m rather unobservant and keep odd hours of waking/sleeping; if I met Dracula without the benefit of cultural knowledge it would probably take me longer lol.
Second, and more importantly, I found Dracula’s whole speech at the end utterly fascinating.  Obviously I don’t have the historical and social context a contemporary reader of this book would have had, so I have no idea what I’m “supposed” to take from the passage.  But personally?  It almost sounds like Dracula (and possibly other vampires?) were like.  Some kind of war leaders?  Or weapons of war?  Or elite warriors?  
Like, reading that passage, I pretty much constructed an entire backstory in my head where Dracula was once able to slake his thirst for blood in battle, and maybe he was venerated and feared as a leader of war, someone who helped protect the region at the expense of his humanity, only as time went on he was needed less and less, and people stop venerating him and only feared him, until he was left alone and forced to subsist on murdering the local peasantry instead of feeding on his fallen enemies like he was supposed to, and any fellow vampires that might have been fighting alongside him had left or died...
Might have just come up with Dracula fanfiction, not sure, but that’s what I got out of the whole speech.

 for an English course years ago and let me tell you something: Dracula Daily is such a more fun way to read this than the normal way of just sitting down with the book
Dracula
 is supposed to be a slowburn horror story, and reading it slowly over the course of months just feels right. Like this is how it was supposed to be read and I was just reading it the wrong way before.

Listen.  My main man Jonathan did a GREAT job finding Dracula the PERFECT home and for this I think he should perhaps be valued by the Count and allowed to live.
And yes Dracula has the distance between his London home and his good pal Jon's home marked and measured on the map.  But, seeing as how he intends to be a true Brit, we need not fear him traveling the distance for anything further than about 2 towns over is further than anyone in England is willing to travel.  They don't road trip. 
So truly, Jonathan is obviously safe.  He'll survive this book!

body:
Dracula Daily, May 7th:
- In love with the image of Dracula lying on the couch reading the 1897 equivalent of a Lonely Planet travel guide
- “it somehow gladdened my heart to see it—the Law List”. Is this literally just a list of lawyers???? History tumblr please explain.
- Dracula: Tell me about the England house.
Jonathan: It’s disgusting, just terrible. Hasn’t been repaired in years, covered in rust, only a few tiny windows covered in iron bars. When I saw it I immediately thought of you.
- Also lol at the image of Johnny trying to get in, being locked out, and instead wandering around an abandoned estate taking pics of things with his “kodak”. I wanted to make a joke about him staggering around with 20 pounds of old-timey camera equipment, but in researching I learned that “by 1897, a folding, pocketable camera had been invented.” Cool! Knowledge acquired!
- Jonathan, PLEASE use this fancy new camera technology to take pics and send them to Mina. The only thing that would make this book better is bad amateur food photography of Paprika Hendl.
No email from my buddy jonathan today hope he’s doing okay :/

body:
I could hear a lot of words often repeated, queer words, for there were many nationalities in the crowd; so I quietly got my polyglot dictionary from my bag and looked them out. I must say they were not cheering to me, for amongst them were "Ordog"—Satan, "pokol"—hell, "stregoica"—witch, 
"vrolok" and "vlkoslak"—both of which mean the same thing, one being Slovak and the other Servian for something that is either were-wolf or vampire. (Mem., I must ask the Count about these superstitions)
Dramatic irony over here making me bust a gut, like "Ah, yes, I must remember to ask my new friend Count Dracula about why everyone keeps talking about vampires around me! I'm sure the Count will know!"

body: We as a society are not talking enough about Dracula's hairy palms.
I love the scenic imagery so much. Our good friend Jonathan is having a grand time appreciating the rocks and mountains and forests while the worried peasants are crossing themselves in the distance

one thing that’s interesting about watching a bunch of 21st century people read and react to dracula at the same time is that SO MANY of the vampire/gothic horror clichés that we are so familiar with today were codified by this very novel so it all maybe seems predictable to us (though trust me, as you move along it 
really isn’t 
as predictable as you think it’s going to be) but at the time it was published, i highly doubt the average reader would make the connection of: “crosses everywhere + creepy castle in remote eastern european location + scared peasants + sketchy guy who only comes out at night = obviously a vampire” bc this novel basically 
invented
 that connection......

body:
I will warn you all I am on the Dracula Daily boat
I haven't read a full book purely for fun since like, high school but having a book delivered in bite sized chunks seems like fun. I got on slightly late but I'm all caught up :)
I love the descriptions, honestly. How Jonathan describes the Carpathian mountains as he rides through them and all the places they pass through is charming, and it's very fun to see all the suspicious details of Dracula and his castle- the missing servants, the odd schedule Dracula keeps, it is all much funnier in hindsight but I am also enjoying reading each entry which is nice. Even the longer ones it's easy to get through because I enjoy the lengthy descriptions. This should be fun!
also I will likely be dracula posting often.
Jonathan ignoring every sign that “ Hey maybe meeting The count is a bad idea” is peak comedy

tags: this is not commentary on the history if this book or what the average victorian person would know I don’t care enough to research that lol
body:
we joke a lot about how funny dracula the novel is because the characters don’t 
know
 they’re in dracula. but it’s cool how something so ingrained in pop culture, 
because
 of how ingrained it is, has become so diluted that a lot of the people reading it for the first time don’t seem to have any idea what to expect beyond “that dude dracula’s def a vampire, and also he hunts people I guess” and like. I don’t think that’s that far from what someone would get from the story without any cultural context/as if it had actually been published for the first time today? 
like it’s going to be shelved as a horror about vampires. it’s titled dracula, we hear about him on page one, and he literally shows up in chapter two being creepy as shit and clearly inhuman in some way. I don’t think “dracula’s the vampire” is 
that
 much of a spoiler lol

Everyone's saying they are receiving letter from their good friend Jonathan, but remember, this is his personal journal, not letters. So, it's more accurately like watching your friend live tweet or post on their Instagram about their business trip, rather than sending personal emails.

i think the power of the rosary is particularly interesting. jonathan is very explicitly CoE, so it’s not a symbol of his faith, and count dracula seems to draw his roots in a pre-christian europe (i haven’t made a thorough study of it, but that is my initial impression) so it’s likely not a symbol of his faith either. it’s a symbol of the faith of the peasants. 
what if it’s not the rosary in and of itself but that it is a gift with a specific intention of protection?
likely that idea gets contradicted later, but if i ever write vampire fiction, i’m running with that.

Reasons I love Tumblr Bookclub over the agony that was AP Lit:
 There’s serious analysis but also silly memes and you’re not called stupid for not taking this Serious Literary Work seriously 
 I don’t have to write essays I can just vibe and gossip
 Posting/replying in the discussion board (tag) is completely optional and has no word/sentence minimum
 We can actually acknowledge the homoerotic undertones

body: I’m so happy people are finally getting into Dracula! It’s one of my all time favorite pieces of literature and I’m so happy an entirely new crowd of people get to enjoy it!
